questions.text: A 57-year-old female patient was diagnosed with carcinoma of the breast and is set to undergo radical mastectomy with dissection of levels 1, 2 and 3 lymph nodes. Which of the following represents level 3 lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The lymph nodes marked as 1 belong to the level 3 axillary nodes.

Lymph nodes are divided into different levels on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis minor.

  • Level 1 lymph nodes: Lateral to the pectoralis minor
  • Level 2 lymph nodes: Superficial or deep to the pectoralis minor
  • Level 3 lymph nodes: Medial to or above the upper border of the pectoralis minor

 

Another method of axillary lymph node classification, as shown in the image below, is based on the anatomical regions that the specific nodes drain.

It can be classified into 5 groups- apical, central, lateral, anterior, and posterior. The apical group receives lymph from the other 4 groups, as well as from the upper part of the breast on the same side.

The image below demonstrates this method of lymph node grouping-

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

Breast conservative surgery is also known as segmental mastectomy, lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, wide local excision, and tylectomy.

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Subcutaneous mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast without overlying skin.
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Axillary lymph nodes (Levels I + II ± III)
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iversion) mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular lymph nodes
  • Super radical mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular + Mediastinal lymph nodes

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors(50% to 65% of tumors) –Range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas(“triple-negative” or “basal-like”) are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital with chest pain for the last 3 hours. Vitals are stable. ECG revealed ST depression and T wave inversion in anterior chest leads. Which of the following would be the most appropriate line of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with sudden onset of chest pain, with ECG findings of ST depression in the anterior chest leads and T wave inversion, the most likely diagnosis is a non-ST-segment elevation-acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS).  The most appropriate line of management in this patient would be to administer aspirin with heparin.

Percutaneous coronary intervention is indicated after coronary angiography in high-risk patients.

Fibrinolytic therapy is not indicated in patients with NSTE-ACS.

Arrhythmia prophylaxis is generally not routinely recommended in all patients with NSTE-ACS.

Acute coronary syndrome is classified into 2 groups:

  • ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
  • NSTE-ACS

NSTE-ACS further includes:

  • NSTEMI (myocyte necrosis present and cardiac troponins elevated)
  • Unstable Angina (myocyte necrosis absent and cardiac troponins not elevated)

The diagnosis of NSTE-ACS is based on the following:

Severe chest discomfort with at least one of 3 features:

  • Occurring at rest or minimal exertion and lasting for more than 10 minutes
  • Recent onset
  • Crescendo pattern

ECG showing:

  • ST segment depression
  • T wave inversion

Elevated cardiac troponins in case of NSTEMI.

Management of NSTE-ACS:

To provide relief of pain and discomfort, initial treatment includes bed rest, nitrates, beta blockers, and inhaled oxygen (only if arterial O2 saturation <90%).

Antithrombotic therapy consisting of antiplatelet and anticoagulant drugs:

  • Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT): Aspirin (162-325 mg) AND one ADP receptor inhibitor (Ticagrelor, clopidogrel or prasugrel)
  • Anticoagulation: Enoxaparin, unfractionated heparin, fondaparinux or bivalirudin
  • An early invasive strategy including diagnostic coronary angiography (within 2–72 hours of presentation) followed by revascularization (percutaneous coronary intervention/ coronary artery bypass grafting) is indicated for stabilized patients who are at high risk of coronary events (Based on TIMI, GRACE or HEART score).

questions.text: The appearance of the liver of a patient with heart failure is shown below. From the following options, identify the sign/symptom that is usually not associated with this condition.
questions.solution:
The above image shows nutmeg liver appearance in congestive hepatomegaly, which is seen in right heart failure. Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea is usually not associated with right heart failure, but it is a sign of left heart failure. The rest of the options are associated with right heart failure.

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver, resembling the cut section of nutmeg. This occurs as a result of hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins, usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

Heart failure is a manifestation of most chronic cardiac conditions such as hypertension, valvular heart disease, and coronary artery disease. Symptoms such as shortness of breath, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (shortness of breath that develops after lying down for 30 minutes or longer) point to left heart failure due to pulmonary congestion. In contrast, symptoms such as pedal oedema, weight gain, early satiety, and hepatic congestion, tender hepatomegaly are characteristic of right heart failure.

Right heart failure Left heart failure
Due to congestion in the systemic circulation Due to congestion in the lungs. 

Symptoms and signs:

  • Raised pulsatile JVP
  • Congestive hepatomegaly
  • Positive hepatojugular reflux
  • Ascites
  • Bilateral pitting oedema 
  • Weight gain due to oedema
  • Fatigue- due to ↓pumping of blood to lungs leading to ↓oxygenation of the blood

Symptoms and signs: 

  • Dyspnea on exertion
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (characteristic of LVF)
  • Pulmonary rales 
  • Increased PCWP
  • Fatigue- due to ↓cardiac output

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to iron toxicity, which is managed with deferoxamine (also known as desferrioxamine). 

Dimercaprol, also known as British anti-Lewisite (BAL), is used to treat arsenic, mercury poisoning, and Wilson's disease. Deferiprone and deferasirox are oral iron chelators used to treat iron overload in thalassemia patients. 

Large amounts of ferrous salts can be fatal in children. Initial symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding. In severe cases, cyanosis and hyperventilation due to acidosis can develop. This can sometimes be followed by an asymptomatic phase. Later, hypoglycemia and hepatic and renal failure can develop. Pyloric stenosis and gastric scarring can develop due to their corrosive nature. Ultimately, if left untreated, the child can die.

The gastric contents can be used for an iron color test to estimate the iron concentration in plasma. As iron tablets are radiopaque, an X-ray can be used to assess the number of pills taken.

Treatment is by whole bowel irrigation for large ingestions, IV hydration, and sodium bicarbonate for academia. IV deferoxamine is an iron chelator indicated in patients with metabolic acidosis, worsening symptoms, systemic toxicity, or a serum iron level predictive of moderate or severe toxicity. Side effects of IV deferoxamine include hypotension and acute respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A slit-lamp examination of a patient showed the following picture. Which of the following is the molecular defect seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the Kayser–Fleischer (KF) ring, which is seen in Wilson's disease. ATP7B is the molecular defect seen in this patient. 

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss of function mutation of the ATP7B gene, which codes for the enzyme copper-transporting ATPase present on the hepatocyte canalicular membrane.

In general, the free copper is taken up by hepatocytes and incorporated to form ceruloplasmin gets released into the bloodstream, and accounts for 90% to 95% of plasma copper. Excess hepatic copper gets transported into the bile and eventually excreted in the faeces.

The defect in the ATP7B gene impairs copper transport into the bile, its incorporation into ceruloplasmin, and secretion of ceruloplasmin into the blood. This results in a decrease in circulating ceruloplasmin levels (<20 mg/dL) and increased levels of hepatic copper. Total serum copper level may be decreased due to the deficiency in ceruloplasmin.

The excessive accumulation of copper injures the hepatocytes. This in turn releases the non-ceruloplasmin-bound copper into the bloodstream, which later gets deposited in tissues like the basal ganglia of the brain and the cornea. This results in behavioural disturbances as well as extrapyramidal symptoms and the characteristic KF ring that is seen on slit-lamp examination. There is a marked compensatory urinary copper excretion. However, these levels do not suffice to prevent the deposition of copper in tissues.

Clinical features of Wilson disease:

  • Hepatomegaly (with or without splenomegaly)
  • Acute/subacute/chronic hepatitis
  • Cirrhosis, ascites, portal hypertension
  • Tremor, dystonia, parkinsonism, behavioral, and psychiatric changes
  • Kayser-Fleischer ring
  • Coomb's negative hemolytic anemia (due to large amounts of copper released from damaged hepatocytes)
  • Renal Fanconi syndrome
  • Endocrinopathies

Important molecule defect and disease:

ATP7A (Option C) Menke’s disease 
ATP7B Wilson disease 
CFTR (Option A) Cystic fibrosis 
SERPINA 1  α-1 antitrypsin deficiency 
ABCC2 (MRP2 protein defect- Option B) Dubin Johnson syndrome

questions.text: A young woman who has recently been on a trekking and camping trip to the Himalayas comes to your clinic with complaints of fever and arthralgia. On examination, you notice facial weakness and a circular expanding annular rash on her right thigh. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has been to the Himalayas presenting with fever, headache, myalgias, facial weakness (facial nerve palsy) and the annular expanding rash (characteristic bull’s eye rash called erythema migrans) is suggestive of Lyme disease.

The causative organism is Borrelia burgdorferi.

Lyme disease is transmitted by the bite of Ixodid ticks (hard ticks).

The disease occurs in 3 stages:

  • Primary stage - characterized by the characteristic bull’s eye rash. The rash starts as a small macule at the site of the tick bite and gradually expands with central clearing.
  • Secondary stage - characterized by secondary annular skin rashes, migratory arthritis, fever, and generalized lymphadenopathy. This stage can be associated with neurological abnormalities like aseptic meningitis and cranial nerve palsies. Patients may also develop myocarditis with associated AV block.
  • Tertiary stage - characterized by chronic arthritis, cranial nerve palsies, ataxia, and dermatitis. 

Doxycycline is the drug of choice in the initial stages of Lyme disease when there is no CNS involvement. If there is CNS involvement, i.v. ceftriaxone is used for treatment.

Option A: Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Clinical features include fever, jaundice, vomiting, headache,  and intense conjunctival injection. The classic presentation of severe leptospirosis is referred to as Weil's disease - a triad of haemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury.  Some may present as aseptic meningitis, or pulmonary leptospirosis with scattered alveolar hemorrhage. The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone.

Option C: Scrub Typhus (also known as chigger-borne typhus) is caused by Rickettsia or Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Option D: Listeriosis caused by Listeria monocytogenes presents as a mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis lasting for 1–3 days. It is usually transmitted by eating infected refrigerated meat and soft cheeses. There may be associated myalgias, arthralgias, backache & headache. 

Related Pearl: Arthropod-borne Diseases

Mosquito Malaria, filaria, Japanese encephalitis, dengue, West Nile fever, yellow fever, etc.
Housefly Typhoid, paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever, oraya fever.
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus (murine typhus), hymenolepis diminuta.
Blackfly (Simulum) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug (Kissing bug/Triatominae) Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, Kyasanur forest disease, tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF)
Soft tick Relapsing fever
Ixodes tick Lyme disease, babesiosis and anaplasmosis.
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus
House mouse mite Rickettsial pox
Itch mite Scabies
Cyclops Guinea worm disease, fish tapeworm
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrans, jigger or chigoe flea) Tungiasis, ulcers in feet/nails.

Related Pearl: Causes of Myocarditis

Infections

Viruses (e.g., coxsackievirus, ECHO, influenza, HIV, cytomegalovirus)

Chlamydiae (e.g.,  Chlamydophila psittaci)

Rickettsiae (e.g., Rickettsia typhi, typhus fever)

Bacteria (e.g., Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Neisseria meningococcus)

Borrelia (Lyme disease)

Fungi (e.g., Candida spp.)

Protozoa (e.g., Trypanosoma cruzi [Chagas disease], toxoplasmosis)

Helminths (e.g., trichinosis)

Immune-Mediated Reactions

Postviral

Poststreptococcal (rheumatic fever)

Systemic lupus erythematosus

Drug hypersensitivity (e.g., methyldopa, sulfonamides)

Transplant rejection

Unknown

Sarcoidosis

Giant cell myocarditis

 Morphology

  • The heart in myocarditis may appear normal or dilated; some hypertrophy may be present depending on disease duration.
  • Mural thrombi may be present.
  • Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with focal myocyte necrosis.
  • Endomyocardial biopsies are diagnostic in some cases, but not when the inflammation is focal or patchy.
  • Hypersensitivity myocarditis: interstitial infiltrates, high proportion of eosinophils
  • Giant-cell myocarditis: multinucleate giant cells (fused macrophages)
  • Chagas disease: Scattered myofibers by trypanosomes.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: In the gynaecology operation theater, preparation for a female sterilization procedure is being made. You notice the instrument in the image below placed on the table. What procedure is going to be performed?
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a falope ring applicator. It is used in laparoscopic tubal ligation. 

Falope ring sterilization is accomplished by applying elastic bands or a falope ring to the fallopian tubes.

The falope ring applicator’s tongs are opened and positioned around the tube approximately 3cm away from the cornu, where the silastic falope ring is applied. It draws up a portion of the tube and then pushes the ring onto the loop of the fallopian tube.

The major advantage is the elimination of thermocoagulation, as the Silastic ring controls most of the bleeding associated with the procedure. The occlusion is complete in a short segment and offers theoretical possibilities of tubal reconstruction. Other methods of laparoscopic tube sterilization include filshie clip sterilization and hulka clip sterilization.

Other options:

Option B: Madlener operation: A loop of the tube is crushed and ligated with a nonabsorbable suture.

Option C: Uchida method: The serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube, and then is excised. The proximal end is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimal excision of the tube preserves the potential for tuboplasty.

Option D: Pomeroy technique: It is the most popular technique of tubal ligation. The fallopian tube is identified, exposed through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop, tied at the base with catgut and excised. Failure of the procedure may later occur due to spontaneous canalization. The operation is simple, requires short hospitalization, and can be performed in a primary health centre. It is surgically reversible.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man presented with complaints of abdominal pain and fever for the past 2 days. Examination shows palmar erythema, testicular atrophy, and distended abdomen with diffuse tenderness. Shifting dullness is present. His vital signs and laboratory findings are given below. He has a history of alcohol consumption for the past 30 years. Which of the following is the next best step in the management?

Vitals and laboratory findings:

  • BP: 138/90 mmHg
  • Pulse: 93 bpm
  • Temp: 101.8 F
  • WBC: 12,500/mm3
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards liver cirrhosis with ascites. The raised temperature and the increased WBC count are most likely due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Paracentesis and ascitic fluid analysis is the next best step in the management of this patient.

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. Abdominal paracentesis within 12 hours of admission is the investigation of choice. The diagnosis of SBP is made when the ascitic fluid has an absolute neutrophil count >250/μL.

Infection with E.coli and other gut bacteria is most commonly seen. However, gram-positive bacteria like Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus sp., can also be found.

Management: The first line of empirical treatment is with a third-generation cephalosporin or a combination of beta-lactam/beta-lactamase agents. In patients who have had an episode of SBP and recovered, prophylactic antibiotics are given to prevent a recurrence.

Other options:

Option A- Liver biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of liver cirrhosis. It determines the grading of inflammation and staging of fibrosis of the liver. Ultrasonography, CT, and MRI are not sensitive to detect liver cirrhosis. It is not the next best step for this patient.

Option B- The administration of fluids is not the best next step for this patient.

Option D- Administration of furosemide and spironolactone is done for the treatment of ascites along with dietary restrictions. However, the patient has a fever and abdominal pain which is a concern for SBP, for which diuresis is not indicated.

questions.text: All of the following are first-line therapeutic agents used in medical management of endometriosis, except:
questions.solution:
GnRH agonists are used as second-line therapeutic agent in medical management of endometriosis.

Medical management of endometriosis:

  • First-line: NSAIDs, low dose oral contraceptives and progestins for 3 to 6 months.
  • Second-line: If first-line therapy fails. Includes High dose progestins, danazol, and GnRH agonists.

Surgical treatment for endometriosis:

It is indicated in large endometriomas of >3 cm in diameter.

  • Definitive therapy: Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with destruction and/or removal of all peritoneal endometriotic implants and adhesions.
  • Fertility preserving therapy: Destruction and/or removal of all peritoneal endometriotic implants and adhesions through a laparoscopic approach or laparotomy.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: What is the use of the following instrument used in orthopaedic surgeries ?

choices.text: To cut bone while performing an osteotomy
To scrape tissue from a cavity or nidus
To hold the plate intact with the bone

questions.solution:
The instrument depicted is a bone curette and it is used for curettage or scraping a cavity in the bone or removing fibrous tissue from the ends of a fracture. It is used in the management of enchondroma, GCT, and osteomyelitis.

Other options -

Option A - An osteotome is used for cutting bone in surgeries such as corrective osteotomies and they are bevelled at both sides.

Option C -A periosteal elevator is used to elevate the periosteum, as nerves and vessels are generally on this plane, and once elevated there is a safer plane for surgery.

Option D: A bone and plate holding forceps is used to hold the plate and bone together in alignment during screw fixation.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a history of myoclonic jerks, seizures, and rapid decline in cognitive function. The mother gives a childhood history of fever with a rash at 18 months of age. The rash had started behind the ears, progressed to involve the whole body, and resolved on its own.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with a classic history of exanthematous fever suggestive of measles, seizures, myoclonic jerks, and cognitive dysfunction is suggestive of subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE).

SSPE is a chronic, progressive demyelinating disease that develops years after measles infection, most often in patients between 5-15 years of age. Patients have a history of measles infection at <2 years of age. CSF shows elevated measles antibody levels and MRI shows increased T2 intensity in white matter. No definitive treatment is available. 

Other complications of measles:

  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Giant-cell pneumonitis
  • Pneumonia
  • Croup
  • Secondary infections - otitis media
  • Protracted diarrhea

questions.text: A young athlete came with recurrent history of pain and locking of the knee. The physician suspects a injury to the menisci. All of the following tests are used for the diagnosis of this condition except:
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of pain and locking of knee has suspected meniscal injury. Lachman test is not used for the diagnosis of this condition. 

Lachman test is also done to detect injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament. In this examination, the patient's knee is flexed at a 20-degree angle. The examiner uses one hand to hold the lower thigh and the other to grasp the upper part of the leg. The joint surfaces are then shifted backward and forwards upon each other. Any abnormal movement observed during this test may indicate a potential anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury.


Meniscal injuries are common injuries seen in athletes who play sports like football and volleyball. Medial meniscal injury is more common(less mobile) than lateral meniscal injury(more mobile). The mechanism of the injury is a rotational force on semi flexed knee. The patient gives a history of pain and locking of the knee while walking or playing.

The following tests are done during the diagnosis of a meniscal tear: 

Apley's test: This test is done with the patient prone, the knee is flexed to 90  degrees and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. This reproduces symptoms if a meniscus is torn. Rotation is then repeated while the leg is pulled upwards by the doctor, holding the thigh down, which is called the distraction test. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.(Option C)


McMurray's test: The patient is positioned in a supine posture with the knee fully flexed. The knee joint is stabilized and palpated using one hand, while the other hand is utilized to internally and externally rotate the leg. Gradual extension of the leg is performed during this examination. If there is any detectable clicking sensation or sound, it may indicate a meniscal injury. (Option B)


Thessaly test: In this test, the affected knee is flexed at a 20-degree angle, and the patient places the foot flat on the ground. While being supported by the examiner, the patient bears their full weight on that leg. They are then instructed to twist their body to one side and then the other, repeating this movement three times, while maintaining the knee flexed at 20 degrees. Individuals with meniscal tears may feel pain along the medial or lateral joint line and may also sense a locking sensation in the knee. (Option D)

Related Pearl: Mechanism of injury and tests for knee injuries

Structures Mechanism of injury Tests

McMurray test

Apley's grinding test

Thessaly test

Lateral collateral ligament Varus force Varus stress test

questions.text: Which of the given investigations has minimum radiation exposure?
questions.solution:
The minimum radiation exposure amongst the given options is for radiograph of an extremity, here, it is the hand radiograph.

Radiation exposure depends on area of exposure, dosage of X rays administered, and the number of films taken.

Values of radiation exposure in mSv(Milli Sievert) are as follows:

  • Extremity X ray- 0.001
  • Dental X rar- 0.005
  • Chest X ray- 0.1
  • Mammogram- 0.4

questions.text: The following instrument is used in:
questions.solution:
The instrument is a stapler pin remover. It is used to removed surgical stapler pins when the wound has healed.

Below shows a craniotomy incision wound which has been closed with stapler pins instead of sutures.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female patient with a history of epilepsy presented with a seizure episode lasting 30 minutes. The seizure activity was resolved after appropriate therapy was given. The patient complained of muscle pain and spasms. He complaints of passing dark colour urine. and investigations showed the following. What is the next best step in management?
Creatine Kinase Markedly increased
Phosphate Increased
Calcium Decreased
Uric acid Elevated
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests prolonged seizure leading to rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury. The next best step in management is volume replacement with IV fluids.  She may require up to 10 L of fluid per day.

Rhabdomyolysis occurred in this patient as a result of prolonged seizure activity causing muscle injury and lysis. As a result, the myoglobin released precipitates in the renal tubules resulting in endogenous kidney injury. Aggressive hydration will prevent further tubular injury.

Once the fluid replacement is adequate, diuretics may be administered if the patient has a urinary flow rate of less than 200-300 ml/hour.

Alkaline fluids like sodium bicarbonate in half-normal saline can help prevent injury to renal tubules. However, it may worsen hypocalcemia. Thus, sodium bicarbonate should only be given in patients who do not have hypocalcemia, whose arterial pH is less than 7.5, and serum bicarbonate is less than 30 mEq/L. 

The focus of acute kidney injury management in the setting of rhabdomyolysis is to maintain fluid and electrolyte status in order to maintain tissue perfusion. 

Other options: 

Option A - Diuretic therapy can be used after adequate volume resuscitation has been administered if the urine output is not satisfactory. However, they should not be used as initial treatment as it can worsen acute kidney injury. 

Option C - Hemodialysis can be used in severe cases of rhabdomyolysis to correct electrolyte imbalances but is not the first-line treatment. 

Option D - Rhabdomyolysis is associated with marked hyperphosphatemia and hypocalcemia. The electrolyte levels should be monitored closely during treatment but they are not the primary focus. 

Related Pearl: Color of urine in different conditions

Normal color of urine is pale straw due to presence of urochrome.

questions.text:
According to the IMNCI guidelines, what is the appropriate rate of rehydration for a two-year-old child suffering from severe dehydration using intravenous fluids?

[IMNCI- Integrated Management of Neonatal & Childhood Illnesses]

choices.text: 30 ml/kg in the first hour, followed by 70 ml/kg in the next five hours
50 ml/kg in the first hour, followed by 50 ml/kg in the next five hours
30 ml/kg in the first 30 minutes, followed by 70 ml/kg in the next 2 ½ hours
50 ml/kg in the first 30 minutes, followed by 50 ml/kg in the next 2 ½ hours

questions.solution:
For a child above 1 year of age, the appropriate rate of rehydration for treating severe dehydration is 30 ml/kg in the first 30 minutes, followed by 70 ml/kg in the next 2 ½ hours.

Children presenting with severe dehydration are started immediately on intravenous fluids preferably Ringer lactate with 5% dextrose. Alternatively, normal saline or plain Ringer solution can also be used.

Children are given a total of 100 ml/kg of fluid for severe dehydration. Children below 1 year of age are administered that amount over 6 hours. Children above 1 year of age are given that amount over 3 hours.

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

 

Plan B: For moderate dehydration, the amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

 

Plan C: For severe dehydration, treatment includes IV fluid administration.

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about gamma knife?

choices.text: It is used for the treatment of tuberculoma
It can be performed anywhere in the body

questions.solution:
Gamma knife is a type of stereotactic radiotherapy or surgery (SRS) which is a reasonable alternative for people who refuse or cannot tolerate surgery. Here, beams are modified and focused only to concentrate on the tumor and have little effect on surrounding tissue. SRS can be done by using: 

  • X-knife using a linear accelerator (LINAC)
  • Gamma-knife using Cobalt 60 as source (Option B)
  • CyberKnife - image-guided linear accelerator using real-time image guidance to deliver radiation from multiple angles.

In gamma knife, the patient wears a specialized helmet called Leksell’s frame that is surgically fixed to the skull. Gamma knife aims gamma radiation through a target point in the patient’s brain. An ablative dose of radiation is thereby sent through the tumour in one treatment session while surrounding brain tissues are relatively spared. 

The classic indications of cobalt-based stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) and gamma knife are:

  • Arterio-venous malformation
  • Acoustic schwannoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Meningioma
  • Trigeminal neuralgia

The image below is an illustration of the priniciple of gamma-knife therapy:

 

Other options:

Option C: It is not used in the treatment of tuberculoma.

Option D: Helmet or frame is needed to perform gamma knife therapies. So, they are limited to brain pathology. Cyberknife uses X-ray (LINAC) and can be performed anywhere in the body with help of a robotic arm.

questions.text: Which of the following group of drugs is not given for post-operative nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
H2 receptor antagonists are used to reduce the risk of aspiration pneumonia, not postoperative nausea and vomiting.

The drugs given for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) act by 

  • 5-HT3 antagonism
  • NK-1 antagonism
  • D2 antagonism

The 5- HT3 receptor mediates vomiting and is found in the gastrointestinal tract and the brain (area postrema). 5-HT3 antagonists like ondansetron and granisetron selectively block the serotonin 5-HT3 receptors, with little or no effect on dopamine receptors.

Substance P is a neuropeptide that interacts with neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptors. NK1 antagonists inhibit substance P at central and peripheral receptors. Aprepitant, an NK1 antagonist, has been found to reduce PONV perioperatively and is additive with ondansetron for this indication. 

Dopamine receptors, particularly D2 and D3 receptors when activated cause nausea and vomiting. Dopamine antagonists like metoclopramide and droperidol block the dopamine receptors at the chemo-receptor trigger zone, thereby reducing PONV.

Risk factors for PONV:

  • Patient-specific: Female gender, non-smoking status, history of motion sickness/PONV
  • Anesthetic-specific: Nitrous oxide, volatile anesthetics, opioids
  • Surgery-specific: Increased duration of surgery, type of surgery

Drugs used in the prophylaxis and treatment of PONV:

  • 5-HT 3 antagonists - ondansetron, palonosetron
  • Butyrophenones- droperidol
  • Dexamethasone
  • Transdermal scopolamine
  • Aprepitant

Note: Propofol has antiemetic property and thus reduces the risk of PONV.

questions.text: Pheochromocytomas are associated with the following syndromes except?
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytoma is associated with MEN-2, Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, and Neurofibromatosis type 1. Cowden syndrome is caused by PTEN mutations and can be associated with multiple hamartomas of skin, breast, and mucous membranes, breast cancer, and neuroendocrine tumors.

Pheochromocytomas may occur in isolation or be associated with hereditary tumor syndromes. The latter include the following tumor syndromes which are characterized by unique germline mutations of genes. 

  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 is characterized by NF1 germline mutations.
  • Familial paraganglioma syndrome - Germline mutations within succinate dehydrogenase complex subunit B (SDHB), SDHD, SDHC genes.
  • MEN2 - Activating germline mutations of RET proto-oncogene.
  • Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome - Germline mutations in VHL gene.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Classical triad of symptoms:
    • Headaches – most common symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction
  • Polyuria and polydipsia 
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: A 45 year male patient with  breathing difficulty and anxiousness came to the emergency department. He has a recent history of pulmonary tuberculosis. His BP is 80/50 mm Hg and the neck veins are distended. An ECG is done. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia. This along with the patient's symptoms suggests a likely diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

Electrical alternans is the beat-to-beat alternation in the ECG waveform. In cardiac tamponade, this is caused by the periodic swinging motion of the heart in a large pericardial effusion. Tuberculosis is a common cause of pleural and pericardial effusion. Raised JVP along with hypotension suggests a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. 

Feature  Cardiac tamponade Constrictive pericarditis Restrictive cardiomyopathy
 Pulsus paradoxus +++ + +/- (Rare)

JVP

 

Prominent x descent
