Prominent y descent - ++ +
Kussmaul's sign -  + +/- (Rare)
Pericardial knock - ++ -
Third heart sound - - +
Electrical alternans ++ - -
Thickened and calcified pericardium - +++ -

questions.text: A primigravida came to the labor room at 40 weeks + 5 days gestation for the induction of labor. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is 1 cm dilated and 3 cm long. The vertex is at -1 station, and the cervix is soft and posterior. What will be the modified Bishop score for this lady?
questions.solution:
The modified Bishop score in this patient is calculated to be 6.

The Bishop score is a scoring system used to assess labor induction outcomes. It is based on the station of the head, dilation, length, position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

Note: In the modified Bishop score (1991) system, effacement is replaced by the cervical length in centimeters.

From the data given in the question:

  • The position of the cervix is posterior, hence score = 0
  • Cervical length is 3 cm, hence score = 1
  • Cervical dilatation is 1 cm, hence score = 1
  • Consistency of cervix is soft, hence score = 2
  • The station of the head is -1, hence score = 2

Hence, the modified Bishop score is 0+1+1+2+2 = 6.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

NOTE: 6-13 seems to be a general consensus for a favorable score.

  • To be specific, according to NICE guidelines -A score of 8 or more generally indicates that the cervix is ripe. 
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (25th edition) - A score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.
  • A score of 5 or less is an indication for induction by cervical ripening agents.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with headache and weakness of the right side of the body. He has difficulty in speaking.  Angiography findings are shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the angiography showing a puff of smoke appearance is suggestive of Moyamoya disease.

Moyamoya disease is an occlusive disease involving the large intracranial arteries.

It has a bimodal age distribution in the first and fourth decades. Childhood moyamoya disease is characterized by ischemic manifestations, whereas adult moyamoya disease is marked by hemorrhagic manifestations.

Vascular inflammation is absent. Since it is a chronic condition, the lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion. This is seen as a puff of smoke (moyamoya in Japanese) on X-ray angiography.

The first symptom is a stroke or recurrent TIA.

Treatment: Surgical bypass of extracranial carotid arteries to the dura or middle cerebral artery may prevent stroke and hemorrhage.

questions.text: A resident doctor suspects a deformity in the hip while doing a routine clinical examination of a 3 day old baby. He performs the following test that is found to be positive. Which of the following investigations is best suited for the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with Ortlani's test positive is suggestive of developmental dysplasia of the hip. Ultrasound of the hip is most useful for the diagnosis of this condition in children less than 6 months old. X-ray is more useful in children more than 6 months since ossification occurs.

Developmental Dysplasia of the hip(DDH): It is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. This condition is more common in females. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip is decreased. The Barlow and Ortolani tests are used for the diagnosis of DDH

The image given below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner’s line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrants formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of DDH

AGE OF THE PATIENT                 MANAGEMENT
Less than 6 months Closed reduction with Pavlik harness or von Rosen splint
6-18 months Closed or open reduction followed by hip spica after reduction
18-36 months Open reduction with femoral osteotomy and pelvic osteotomy (Salter's osteotomy, Pemberton osteotomy, Steel osteotomy)
3-8 year Open reduction with femoral shortening and pelvic osteotomy 
8-18 year

Open procedure with femoral shortening with pelvic osteotomy or total hip replacement

questions.text: The image shown below is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an exclamation mark hair sign which is a characteristic feature seen in Alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes nonscarring patches of hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed patients.

The most characteristic lesion initially is a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia which has short extractable broken hairs called exclamation mark hair.

Other options:

Option B: Patients with telogen effluvium demonstrate empty follicles and regrowing hairs of normal thickness on dermoscopy.

Option C: Netherton syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. Patients with this disease present with lustreless, dry, short hair. On trichoscopy, patients may have a characteristic bamboo hair defect due to the collapse of the distal hair shaft into the proximal hair shaft secondary to defective keratinization.

Option D: Primary cicatricial alopecias are inflammatory disorders that lead to permanent hair loss

questions.text: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote?
questions.solution:
The above pedigree chart denotes an autosomal recessive pattern. In the above pedigree chart, both males and females are carriers (equally affected) which indicates an autosomal pattern. Parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes), and no affected members in other generations. 25% of the children are normal, 50% are carriers, and only 25% are affected. This indicates a a recessive pattern. 

Pedigree charts in various modes of inheritance:

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with pseudologia fantastica?
questions.solution:
Patients with Munchausen syndrome (factitious disorder) demonstrate pseudologia fantastica, a specific syndrome of autobiographical lying with four features:

  1. The stories are not entirely improbable and are built upon a basis of truth.
  2. The stories are enduring.
  3. They are not told purely for personal gain and have a self-aggrandizing quality.
  4. They are not delusions, in that the patient can admit to falsehoods when confronted with conflicting facts.

In pseudologia fantastica, limited factual material is mixed with extensive and colourful fantasies. The listener's interest pleases the patient and, thus, reinforces the symptom.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient came with complaints of breathlessness that worsens on exertion and fatiguability for a few months. She gives a history of radiotherapy for carcinoma breast 6 months back. On examination,  bilateral lower limb pitting edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign were present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman presenting post-irradiation with progressive exertional dyspnea, bilateral lower extremity edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign is suggestive of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by diastolic dysfunction of a non-dilated ventricle with, mildly decreased contractility and ejection fraction.

Most of the cases are due to the infiltration of abnormal substances between myocytes like amyloidosis, abnormal metabolic products within myocytes as seen in hemochromatosis/Fabry's disease, or fibrotic injury like radiation/scleroderma.  

They often present with right-sided heart symptoms like edema, ascites, and abdominal discomfort. A fourth heart sound is predominately heard than a third heart sound and is often associated with atrial fibrillation. JVP shows rapid y descent and may increase with inspiration.

Kussmaul's sign is an indication of restrictive cardiomyopathy.

Kussmaul's sign is a paradoxical rise or failure in the appropriate fall of jugular venous pressure (JVP) with inspiration. It is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis.

Normally, during inspiration, the JVP falls due to negative intrathoracic pressure. When there is an impairment in the expansion of the right ventricle or a raise in the right atrial pressure, there is a back pressure of blood in the jugular veins. This causes a paradoxical rise in the JVP during inspiration instead of a fall.

Kussmaul's sign can also be associated with

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarction
  • Advanced left ventricular systolic heart failure

Other options:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy presents with symptoms and signs of left heart failure or biventricular heart failure. Patients show cardiomegaly, and a third heart sound can be auscultated. The most frequent causes are alcoholism, myocarditis, chemotherapy, and endocrinopathies. Echocardiogram shows left ventricular dilation and dysfunction.

Option B: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy presents with dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope. Examination reveals bisferiens carotid pulse. A fourth heart sound and variable systolic murmur can be auscultated. It is an inherited autosomal disease with variable penetrance. They are caused by mutation of the gene encoding for myosin heavy chains or proteins regulating calcium handling. The echocardiogram is the diagnostic tool. Any area of left ventricle thickness more than 1.5 cm confirms the disease.

Option D: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy presents as acute anterior myocardial infarction, with acute chest pain or shortness of breath. It occurs soon after a high catecholamine surge and is seen predominantly in postmenopausal women.  Cardiac catheterization shows normal coronaries. The LV appears as a round ampulla, resembling the Japanese octopus pot called takotsubo pot. Imaging reveals apical left ventricular ballooning due to myocardial stunning. 

The image below shows a ventriculogram showing takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
A patient presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and oliguria for 3 days. On examination, swelling around the eyes and both ankles was noted. The results of his laboratory investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum findings:

Serum creatinine: 2.28 mg/dL

Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 80 mg/dL

Serum uric acid: 4 mg/dL 

Urine findings:

Specific gravity: 1.024

Urine sodium: 16 mEq/L

(AKI - acute kidney injury)

choices.text: The patient does not have AKI

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of prerenal AKI based on the following:

  • Urine specific gravity >1.018
  • Urinary sodium < 20 meq/L
  • BUN: Creatinine ratio > 20:1 (80÷2.28≈35) 

Differences between prerenal and renal AKI:

Indices Prerenal Renal
Spot urine sodium (mEq/L) <20 >40
Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) <1% >2%
Fractional excretion of urea (FEUrea) <35% >35%
Urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) >500 <350
BUN to serum creatinine ratio >20:1 <10:1
Urine creatinine/plasma creatinine >40:1 <20:1
Urinary sediment Nil or hyaline casts only Renal tubular epithelial casts, muddy brown granular casts
Urinary specific gravity >1.018 <1.010

 

Serum uric acid levels are normal in this patient. If found elevated, along with features of renal AKI, it can point towards a diagnosis of tumor lysis syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following types of psoriasis cannot be treated with methotrexate?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate can be given in all types of psoriasis except impetigo herpetiformis, also known as acute generalized pustular psoriasis of pregnancy. The drug of choice for impetigo herpetiformis is systemic steroids.

Impetigo herpetiformis typically presents during the last trimester of pregnancy. It may persist until the delivery of the child, however, it may even persist longer. Clinical features include:

  • Characteristic erythematous patches with marginal grouped sterile pustules
  • Flexures affected, symmetrical
  • Centrifugal extension from the inguino-genital region
  • Grouping of areas of pustulation
  • Erosions and crusts may be present
  • Residual reddish-brown pigmentation as healing occurs.
  • Nail, mucosal lesions in tongue, mouth, and oesophagus
  • May be associated with hypothyroidism and hypocalcemia

Below is an image showing annular lesions on the left thigh of a patient with pustular psoriasis of pregnancy. 

The mainstay of treatment is systemic corticosteroids. If unresponsive to corticosteroids, cyclosporine can also be started. Antibiotics like cephalosporins are found to be effective as an additive treatment, even though the pustules are sterile. Narrowband UVB is considered another safe treatment when there is not an adequate response to steroids.

Complications like intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), premature rupture of membranes (PROM), and placental insufficiency are also seen. Death of the mother may occur due to cardiac or renal failure. Recurrence is common.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice
Chronic Plaque Psoriasis Methotrexate
Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate 
Psoriatic Arthritis Methotrexate / Apremilast
Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin
Psoriasis in HIV patients Acitretin
Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine
Erythrodermic Psoriasis in Pregnancy Systemic Corticosteroids

questions.text: A baby is brought to hospital for circumcision.  All are true regarding circumcision except _____.

choices.text: Hemorrhage due to bleeding from frenular artery

questions.solution:
Circumcision is often performed in the neonatal period, infancy, or childhood for cultural or religious reasons and is also performed after the newborn period, when phimosis, paraphimosis, balanoposthitis, or when sexually transmitted diseases are more prevalent. It does not increase the sexual drive.

Medical benefits of circumcision:

  • Reduced urinary infections in infancy
  • Decreased incidence of sexually transmitted disease
  • Marked reduction in the incidence of penile carcinoma

Complications of circumcision:

  • Bleeding is the most frequent complication and occurs in approximately 0.1% of cases.
  • Most infections are minor and superficial, manifested by redness and occasionally purulence at the circumcision site that usually responds to local wound care.
  • A common complication of neonatal circumcision is meatal stenosis, probably produced by a chemical meatitis from ammoniacal urine exposure on the tip of the penis while the patient is still wearing diapers.
  • Serious complications are rare but include recurrent phimosis, wound separation, major tissue loss, concealed penis, skin bridges between the shaft and the glans, inclusion cysts, urethrocutaneous fistula, and loss of some of the glans or, extremely rarely, all of the penis.

Contraindications for circumcision:

  • prematurity
  • anomalies of the penis (like chordee, or curvature of the penis)
  • hypospadias
  • epispadias
  • concealed or buried penis
  • micropenis
  • webbed penis
  • ambiguous genitalia

Bleeding diatheses are not absolute contraindications for circumcision, but it should be avoided in these cases.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with complaints of persistent fever, and cough for 3 weeks. The child's mother is a known case of tuberculosis and is on treatment. As per the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme guidelines, what should be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the child is exposed to tuberculosis and has symptoms suggestive of tuberculosis. Therefore the next step in management is to do sputum CBNAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test). CBNAAT is the investigation of choice.

Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT) provides an accurate and rapid diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Rifampicin (Rif) resistance-conferring mutations, in sputum specimens as well as a specimen from extra-pulmonary sites. CBNAAT is recommended for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB preferentially in the key population such as children, PLHIV, Extra-pulmonary TB, and in smear-negative TB as per the diagnostic algorithm. 

Sputum smear microscopy(Option C) is done if CBNAAT facilities are not available. Chest X-ray (Option B) and Mantoux test or tuberculin skin test (Option D) are done if MTB is not detected or sputum is not available.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

A presumptive pulmonary TB patient should undergo both Sputum examination and Chest X-ray.

If sputum and CXR is negative, CB NAAT should be done when the clinical suspicion is high:

As is inferred from the above table, irrespective of chest X ray findings, CB-NAAT is done in all cases where sputum examination is negative for diagnosis.

CB-NAAT is also performed in all microbiologically confirmed and notified cases of TB for drug susceptibility testing.

The following protocol is used for CB-NAAT testing:

questions.text: Which of the following  is seen in placenta previa?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, placenta previa shows warning bleeds.

Dark painful bleeding with a tender uterus that is disproportionately enlarged is seen in placental abruption.

Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment either over or close to the internal cervical os.

Risk factors for placenta previa

  • Multigravida
  • Age > 35 years
  • Smoking
  • Previous cesarean section or myomectomy
  • Abnormal placental size and lobes
  • Prior curettage

Clinical features of placenta previa:

  • Sudden-onset recurrent painless vaginal bleeding: First bleeding usually appears after the end of the second trimester or later and is usually mild and not fatal. This is called ‘Sentinel bleed’.  In about one ­third of cases, there is a history of ‘warning hemorrhage’ which is usually slight.
  • The size of the uterus corresponds to gestational age. 
  • The uterus is relaxed, soft, no tenderness 
  • Floating head 
  • Fetal heart sound is present unless there is major separation and the patient is exsanguinated.
  • Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis which recovers promptly as pressure is relieved is suggestive of a low-lying placenta especially of posterior type: Stallworthy sign.

Degree of placenta previa:

There are four types of placenta previa depending upon the degree of extension of the placenta to the lower segment

  • Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the internal os.
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

Per-Vaginal Examination should not be done in suspected Placenta Previa, whereas it can be only done in the operation theatre with all the arrangements for C-section.

The image below shows the types of placenta previa.

Expectant management for placenta previa was advocated by Macafee and Johnson. The aim is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. 

Prerequisites 

  • Availability of blood for transfusion whenever required 
  • Facilities for cesarean section should be available 24 h. 

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  • Mother in good health (Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%) 
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  • No active vaginal bleeding 
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG) 

Conduct of expectant treatment

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity if <34 wk
    • Betamethasone 12mg IM 24 hours apart for 2 doses or
    • Dexamethasone 6mg IM 12 hours apart for 4 doses
  • Bedrest 
  • Hb, Blood grouping and urine for protein 
  • Inspection of vulval pads, fetal surveillance with USG
  • Supplementary hematinics 
  • Rh Immunoglobin should be given to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women
  • Use of tocolytics if there are uterine contractions.

The pregnancy is carried till 37 weeks as part of expectant management. During this time, if there is fetal distress or a bleeding episode, then terminate immediately.

questions.text: A young, previously healthy man presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath that occurred at rest. His BP is 132/90 in both arms, RR is 21, HR: 120. He reports snorting cocaine about an hour ago.  An EKG shows ST segment elevations, and troponins are normal. Sublingual nitroglycerin promptly relieves his chest pain. What is the most likely mechanism of his chest pain?
questions.solution:
This patient appears to be having symptoms and EKG signs of Prinzmetal/Variant/Vasospastic angina, likely due to cocaine use.

Cocaine inhibits monoamine (dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine, and serotonin) reuptake and acts as a vasoconstrictor - can lead to a decrease in blood flow to the heart: Chest pain, and shortness of breath. This sympathetic stimulation can occur at all concentrations of cocaine and causes hypertension and ventricular ectopics. Cocaine can also increase heart rate and blood pressure, which further worsens these symptoms. The first-line agents that are used are calcium channel blockers (CCBs) and nitrates.

Prinzmetal angina occurs as a result of vasospasm of the epicardial coronary artery. It may result in transient transmural ischemia. The cause of this spasm is poorly understood and is suspected to be due to hypercontractility of cardiac smooth muscles. This type of angina is commonly seen in women under 50 years of age and is precipitated by smoking and cocaine use.

The vasospasm leads to transmural ischemia, which is seen on the ECG as transient ST-segment elevation although there is no atherosclerosis present on angiography. 

Depolarization of cardiac myocytes depends primarily on the influx of Ca2+ ions. Ca 2+ antagonists relax arterial smooth muscle, thereby decreasing arterial resistance, blood pressure, and cardiac afterload. Hence, calcium channel blockers such as long-acting nifedipine and amlodipine are employed along with nitrates to alleviate vasospasm.

Cocaine is obtained from the plant Erythroxylum coca. The symptoms of cocaine poisoning are divided into two stages:

  1. Stage of excitement: This stage is characterized by features like dysphagia, dryness in the mouth, tachycardia, and dilated pupils. The reflexes are exaggerated and are associated with tingling and numbness in the hands and feet. 
  2. Stage of depression: This stage presents with feeble respiration, profuse sweating, convulsions, and death. In most cases, the cause of death is cardiopulmonary failure or vascular collapse.

 

Chronic users develop a feeling of insects crawling through the skin or the presence of grains of sand under the skin. This is pathognomic for cocaine poisoning and is known as cocaine bugs or Magnan's symptoms/syndrome. Ulceration and sometimes perforation of the nasal septum are seen in chronic abusers due to the sniffing habit.

Option A: Aortic dissection clinically presents with tearing chest/back pain associated with diaphoresis, syncope, weakness, and dyspnea or neurological manifestations. Unequal pulses or widely discordant blood pressure in the extremities may be seen due to changes of flow in the true and false lumens. There can be hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, findings of aortic regurgitation, and pulmonary edema. It is unlikely in this patient who has equal pulses and pain relief with nitroglycerin,

Option B: Pulmonary embolism is unlikely in this patient with no risk factors or comorbidities. Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and tachypnea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only a few cases.

Option D: Myocardial Infarction is more likely to occur in people with underlying heart disease, such as coronary artery disease. Moreover, troponin would be elevated in case of MI.

questions.text: What is the most common mode of spread in ovarian malignancies ?
questions.solution:
The transcoelomic route is the most common and the earliest mode of spread in ovarian malignancies.

By this route, tumor cells spilled into the peritoneal cavity follow the path of the peritoneal fluid during respiration and get deposited in areas such as the paracolic gutter, cul-de-sac (pouch of Douglas), hemidiaphragm, mesenteries of the intestine, and the liver capsule.

Lymphatics is the next common mode of spread, especially in the advanced stages of the disease. The common sites involved are the para-aortic and pelvic nodes.

Hematogenous spread is uncommon and can seed a nidus in the parenchyma of organs such as the lung and the liver.Right pleural effusion is a common finding. This mode of spread mostly occur in survivors of the malignancy.

Transcoelomic spread > lymphatic spread > hematogenous spread

questions.text: A young man presented with seizures refractory to medication. The finding on the skull X-Ray is shown below. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows bracket calcification which is seen in the lipoma of the corpus callosum.

Majority of the lipomas arise near the corpus callosum. These tumors have marginal calcification where they merge with the adjacent cortical tissues. This gives rise to the characteristic bracket appearance. Intracranial lipomas are asymptomatic. Epileptic seizures are common and are occasionally refractory to anticonvulsant treatment.

Other options:

Option A- Sturge–Weber syndrome shows the following features:

  • Facial port-wine stain along the course of the trigeminal nerve
  • Ipsilateral venous angiomas in the cortical leptomeninges
  • Mental retardation
  • Seizures, hemiplegia
  • Skull radio-opacities i.e tram track calcification.

 Below image shows Tram track calcification

Option B- Tuberous sclerosis shows cortical tubers and calcification of ependymal nodules in the wall of ventricles. 

Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder caused by mutations in the TSC1 (chromosome 9) or TSC2 (chromosome 16) genes, which code for hamartin and tuberin respectively. 

Tuberous sclerosis presents usually at a young age. Patients may have retinal hamartomas, cardiac rhabdomyoma, renal angiomyolipomas, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas. The patients present with characteristic cutaneous signs. The first cutaneous sign that develops is the ash leaf macule, which is a macular hypomelanotic patch, commonly seen on the lower back. Another cutaneous manifestation is the shagreen patch, which is a hypermelanotic nevus. It is located in the lumbosacral region. The characteristic bumps that develop on the face are called adenoma sebaceum or facial angiofibromas.

The image below shows the characteristic ash leaf macule.

The below image shows adenoma sebaceum.

 

The below image shows Shagreen patch 

Option D- Meningioma on X-Ray shows calcification, hyperostosis of adjacent bone, and increased vascular markings, it is usually seen falx. Imaging shows the presence of a dural tail sign.

questions.text: Out of 100 women who took oral contraceptive pills for contraception, 10 women got pregnant within 24 months. What is the Pearl index?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pearl index is 5 per HWY.

Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 10. There are 100 couples who are exposed to the method.

So, the total months of exposure are 24 months x 100 = 2400.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

Hence, pearl index = 10 x 1200/2400 = 5 per HWY. 

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease has elevated serum creatinine and urea levels. Which of the following oral hypoglycemic agents is safe to use?
questions.solution:
Linagliptin does not require dose adjustment with renal failure and is a safe oral hypoglycemic drug to use in patients with chronic kidney disease.

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or in combination therapy when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated. It binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system. Hence, no dose adjustment is needed in renal failure.

Other options:

Option A: Glimepiride is a second-generation sulfonylurea that is excreted by the kidneys and hence cannot be used in renal failure.

Option B: Exenatide is a GLP-1 agonist excreted by the kidneys and hence cannot be used in renal failure.

Option C: Vildagliptin and other DPP-4 inhibitors (saxagliptin, sitagliptin, and alogliptin) are largely excreted by the kidneys and cannot be used in chronic renal failure.

questions.text:
Which of the following are extra-esophageal complications associated with GERD?
  1. Asthma
  2. Laryngitis
  3. Pulmonary fibrosis
  4. Cough
questions.solution:
Asthma,laryngitis,pulmonary fibrosis and cough are extra esophageal complications in gastroesophageal reflux disease(GERD)
 
 Extraoesophageal symptoms of GERD are:

  • Chronic cough
  • Laryngitis,
  • Asthma
  • Dental erosions (especially on the lingual and palatal tooth
    surfaces).
  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Sinusitis
  • Pharyngitis
  • Recurrent otitis media

Extraesophageal symptoms of GERD originate from the respiratory tract and include both laryngeal and pulmonary issues These symptoms can arise through two mechanisms. The first and most common mechanism involves proximal esophageal reflux and microaspiration of gastroduodenal contents, which cause direct injury to the larynx and lower respiratory tract. The second mechanism involves distal esophageal acid exposure triggering a vagal nerve reflex, leading to bronchospasm and cough, due to the shared vagal innervation of the trachea and esophagus.

The incidence of Barrett's esophagus is also more in patients with long term GERD, which in turn increases the risk of adenocarcinoma of esophagus.

questions.text: An elderly lady complains of recurrent right-sided headaches, nonspecific shoulder pain, and jaw pain on chewing for 6 months. ESR is 107mm/hr. Which of the following features would be characteristically seen in a biopsy specimen obtained from her?

choices.text: Multinucleated cells in the arterial intima and media
Eosinophils and neutrophils in the arterial intima and media
Lymphocytes and plasma cells in the arterial adventitia
Fibrinoid necrosis of the arterial wall

questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent headaches, jaw claudication and non specific shoulder pain (likely polymyalgia rheumatica) with an elevated ESR most likely has giant cell arteritis. The presence of multinucleated cells, or giant cells in the arterial intima and media is the most suggestive biopsy feature of Giant cell arteritis (GCA). 

GCA is a chronic, large-vessel vasculitis that commonly affects the temporal arteries, but can also involve the aorta, its branches, and the ophthalmic arteries. It is the most common vasculitis in adults over 50 years.

Histopathology also shows panarteritis with infiltration of inflammatory mononuclear cells with giant cell formation. Intimal thickening and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina are also seen (black arrow). Multinucleated giant cells are large cells with multiple nuclei that are formed by the fusion of macrophages (yellow arrow). They are a hallmark of GCA and are not typically seen in other types of vasculitis.

There is thickening and narrowing of the artery, resulting in thrombosis, ischemia or aneurysms. Symptoms include headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, visual disturbances, fever, fatigue, and weight loss. It is also associated with mononeuritis multiplex; peripheral neuropathy in two or more separate nerve areas. A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness. 

Elevated ESR and anaemia are characteristic laboratory findings. Raised liver enzymes, especially alkaline phosphatase are common. Levels of IgG and complement may be raised. GCA is treated with corticosteroids.

Other options:

Option B: Eosinophils and neutrophils can be seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome and Polyarteritis Nodosa. 

Option C: Lymphocytes and plasma cells are seen in many types of inflammation, including GCA, but are not specific.

Option D: Fibrinoid necrosis of the arterial wall can be seen in GCA, but is also seen in Polyarteritis Nodosa.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions in a child would not be associated with a head circumference <3 SD below the mean for age and sex?

Standard deviation- SD
questions.solution:
Of the conditions listed, achondroplasia is not linked to microcephaly, which is defined as a head circumference below 3 SD from the mean for age and sex, whereas all other conditions are associated with it.

Head circumference in a child is measured as the maximum circumference from the external occipital protuberance to the supraorbital ridges and is one of the important anthropometric measurements in the assessment of growth and development. Based on this:

  • Microcephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference <3 SD below the mean for age and sex.
  • Macrocephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference >2 SD above the mean for age and sex.

Important causes of microcephaly include:

  • Syndromic: Trisomies 21, 18, 13, Monosomy 1p36 deletion
  • Neural tube defects
  • Perinatal Insult: Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, hypoglycemia
  • Metabolic disorders: Phenylketonuria, methylmalonic aciduria, citrullinemia 
  • Maternal Infections: congenital CMV, varicella, toxoplasmosis, HIV, syphilis
  • Maternal teratogens like alcohol, tobacco, marijuana, cocine, antiepileptics
  • Endocrine causes: Hypothyroidism, hypopituitarism, adrenal insufficiency
  • Craniosynostosis

Important causes of macrocephaly include:

  • Familial syndromes: Neurofibromatosis, Tuberous Sclerosis, Sturge-Weber, Fragile X
  • Lysosomal storage diseases: Tay-Sachs disease, mucopolysaccharidosis, gangliosidosis, 
  • Hydrocephalus 
  • Intracranial haemorrhage (subdural, extradural, intraventricular) and AVMs
  • Intracranial mass lesions like cyst, abscess or tumor
  • Bone disease like achondroplasia, osteogenesis imperfecta, osteopetrosis
  • Bone marrow expansion: Thalassemia 
  • Raised intracranial pressure: Idiopathic pseudotumor cerebri, lead poisoning, hypervitaminosis A, galactosemia

questions.text: A researcher wants to combine twenty different clinical trials to assess the effect of a drug used for Parkinson's disease. Which of the following best explains the type of study conducted?
questions.solution:
The type of study described here is a meta-analysis that involves combining results from multiple studies on a given topic.

Meta-analysis is the quantitative analysis of the results obtained from a systematic review. A systematic review uses certain inclusion and exclusion criteria to review multiple studies. By combining the results of multiple studies, the power of analysis and generalizability is increased.

Other options

Option A:  A cohort study is a type of analytical study that is done to support or refute an association between a suspected cause and disease. It can be prospective, retrospective, or a combination of the two. The cohorts are selected prior to the appearance of the disease being studied in prospective studies. In retrospective studies, the outcome has already occurred before the start of the study.

Option B: A case-control study is another type of analytical study. It is often called retrospective studies. It is a common method used to test causal hypotheses initially. It proceeds from effect to cause. Both the exposure and outcome have already occurred before the start of the study. It has a control and comparison group.

Option D: A randomized control trial (RCT) is used to evaluate methods of treatment and prevention by scientific techniques. By randomization, the participants are divided into two groups - study and control. The former group receives the procedure or intervention while the latter does. This helps to eliminate bias and ensures comparability. 

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A 55 year male presented with a lesion on his foot. What is the likely diagnosis of the lesion shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image showing a punched-out ulcer with regular margins located on the plantar surface of the foot points to the diagnosis of a neuropathic ulcer.

In peripheral neuropathy, lack of sensation over the pressure points leads to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that go unnoticed eventually developing into ulcers.

Type of Ulcer Ischaemic/Arterial Venous Neuropathic Tuberculous  
Underlying condition

Peripheral vascular disease mainly atherosclerosis, thromboangitis obliterans, and Raynaud's phenomenon

 Varicose veins, previous deep vein thrombosis Diabetes, peripheral neuropathy Tuberculosis lymph nodes, cold abscess from bone and joint tuberculosis
Location Toes, feet, legs, or even upper limb digits Lower limb, commonly on the medial side of the ankle, never above the middle third of the leg The plantar surface of the foot and toes Neck, axilla, and groin
Characteristics

Deep, penetrates the deep fascia exposing the tendons, muscles, and underlying bone. The ulcer is painful, tender, and hyperaesthetic. 

 Vertically oval, and painless. The floor may have pale to no granulation tissue, induration, and tenderness at the base. Punched-out with regular calloused margins. 

Edges are thin, reddish blue, and undermined. Pale granulation tissue, scanty discharge on the floor, and slight induration at the base
Other features Features of ischemia in adjacent areas, like pallor, dry skin, brittle nails, loss of hair Inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged usually the vertical group. The ulcer is recurrent. Dry, cracked, insensate Regional lymph nodes are enlarged, non-tender, and matted

 

The following image depicts a venous ulcer. 

The following image depicts a tuberculous ulcer. 

The image below shows an arterial ulcer.

questions.text: A 3-week neonate presents with ambiguous genitalia with Na+ - 127;  K+ - 5.5 meq/L with a BP of 50/22 mm Hg. Along with IV fluids, what is the next step in management ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical case of a neonate presenting with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension points towards a diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Hydrocortisone must be administered along with IV fluids for the management of this baby.

The most common enzyme deficiency in CAH is 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Babies with 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically present around 10-14 days of age with the subset of symptoms due to aldosterone deficiency, cortisol deficiency, and androgen excess.

Aldosterone deficiency leads to salt-wasting crises marked by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis.

Cortisol deficiency causes manifestations like hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation, weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock.

Androgen excess in 21-hydroxylase deficiency results in virilization of females, leading to female pseudohermaphroditism, and precocious puberty in males. Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.

Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Diagnosis is confirmed by elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels or by genetic testing.

Glucocorticoid replacement therapy is the primary treatment for cortisol deficiency, aiming to suppress androgen production and prevent complications associated with androgen excess. Fludrocortisone is given to control mineralocorticoid deficiency. 

If the condition is diagnosed prenatally, dexamethasone may be administered to the mother. 

The image below summarizes the pathway involved in steroid hormonal production:

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-Hydroxylase 17-Hydroxylase 11β-Hydroxylase 3β-HSD

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone;

↑ in testosterone

 Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones; ↑ in aldosterone Deficiency of cortisol; ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone and testosterone; ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency, Aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Increased intracranial pressure is considered an absolute contraindication to spinal anesthesia because of the risk of brainstem herniation.

The other factors listed are considered relative contraindications.

Other options: 

Option B: Spinal stenosis  increases the risk of neurologic complications. However, a lower mass of local anesthetic reduces the risk in such patients.

Option C: Previous spine surgery does not necessarily increase the risk of neurologic complications. Factors such as postsurgical scarring and local anatomy are considered in such situations.

Option D: Peripheral neuropathy has not been found to be worsened by spinal anesthesia, and hence it is considered a relative contraindication. 

Related Pearl: Order of block in spinal anaesthesia

  • Autonomic preganglionic sympathetic
  • Temperature
  • Pin prick
  • Pain
  • Touch
  • Pressure
  • Motor

Related Pearl: Contraindications for Spinal anesthesia

Absolute

  • Infection at the site of injection
  • Patient refusal
  • Increased intracranial pressure
  • Allergy to the anesthetic drugs
  • Coagulopathy or other bleeding diathesis
  • Severe hypovolemia
  • Severe aortic stenosis
  • Severe mitral stenosis

Relative

  • Sepsis
  • Uncooperative patient
  • Preexisting neurological deficits
  • Demyelinating lesions
  • Stenotic valvular heart lesions
  • Left ventricular outflow obstruction (hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy)
  • Severe spinal deformity

questions.text: All the following can result in non-immune hydrops except
questions.solution:
ABO incompatibility is not a cause of nonimmune hydrops.

Hydrops is diagnosed by identifying two or more fetal effusions—pleural, pericardial, or ascites—or one effusion plus anasarca. Hydrops can be seen in association with red cell auto immunization, which is termed immune hydrops. Otherwise, it is nonimmune. Pathogenesis of hydrops includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability.

Etiology of hydrops fetalis

Cardiovascular

  • Structural defects: Ebstein anomaly, tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve, hypoplastic left or right heart, premature closure of ductus arteriosus, arteriovenous malformation (vein of Galen aneurysm)
  • Cardiomyopathies
  • Tachyarrhythmias
  • Bradycardia, as may occur in heterotaxy syndrome with endocardial cushion defect or with anti-Ro/La antibodies

Chromosomal

  • Turner syndrome (45,X), triploidy, trisomies 21, 18, and 13

Hematological

  • Hemoglobinopathies, such as α4 thalassemia
  • Erythrocyte enzyme and membrane disorders
  • Erythrocyte aplasia/dyserythropoiesis
  • Decreased erythrocyte production (myeloproliferative disorders)
  • Fetomaternal hemorrhage

Lymphatic Abnormalities

  • Cystic hygroma, systemic lymphangiectasis, pulmonary lymphangiectasis

Infections

  • Parvovirus B19, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella, enterovirus, varicella, herpes simplex, coxsackievirus, listeriosis, leptospirosis, Chagas disease, Lyme disease

Syndromic

  • Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita, lethal multiple pterygium, congenital lymphedema, myotonic dystrophy type I, Neu-Laxova, Noonan, and Pena-Shokeir syndromes

Thoracic Abnormalities

  • Cystic adenomatoid malformation
  • Pulmonary sequestration
  • Diaphragmatic hernia
  • Hydro/chylothorax
  • Congenital high airway obstruction sequence (CHAOS)
  • Mediastinal tumors
  • Skeletal dysplasia with very small thorax

Gastrointestinal  

  • Meconium peritonitis, gastrointestinal tract obstruction

Kidney and Urinary Tract

  • Kidney malformations
  • Bladder outlet obstructions
  • Congenital (Finnish) nephrosis, Bartter syndrome, mesoblastic nephroma

Placental, Twin, and Cord Abnormalities

  • Placental chorioangioma, twin-twin transfusion syndrome, twin reversed arterial perfusion sequence, twin anemia polycythemia sequence, cord vessel thrombosis

Other Rare Disorders

  • Inborn errors of metabolism: Gaucher disease, galactosialidosis, GM1 gangliosidosis, sialidosis, mucopolysaccharidoses, mucolipidoses
  • Tumors: sacrococcygeal teratoma, hemangioendothelioma with Kasabach-Merritt syndrome

Idiopathic

questions.text: A 32-year-old P2L2 lady comes on the fifth day of unprotected sexual intercourse. What will be your advice for contraception for this lady?

choices.text: Two tablets of high dose OCP, repeated after 24 hours

questions.solution:
Copper IUCD should be advised for contraception for this lady.

Copper-IUD is an effective postcoital contraceptive method and can be inserted up to 5 days following unprotected intercourse. It is the most effective method for emergency contraceptives. The advantages of Copper-T as emergency contraception are as follows:

  • It can be inserted as late as 5 days after unprotected intercourse.
  • It is cheap.
  • Failure rate is 0.1%.
  • It can remain an ongoing contraceptive method for 3-5 years.

Contraindications for copper-IUD:

  • Uterine abnormality with the distorted uterine cavity
  • Acute PID, or current behavior suggesting a high risk for PID
  • Postpartum endometritis or postabortal endometritis in the past 3 months
  • Known or suspected uterine or cervical malignancy
  • Genital bleeding of unknown etiology
  • Mucopurulent cervicitis
  • Wilson disease
  • Allergy to copper
  • A previously placed IUD that has not been removed

Other options:

Option A: Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg (not 0.75 mg, single dose as in the question), i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg, can be used as a single-dose emergency contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. The tablets can be offered for up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in the interval between coitus and drug intake.

Option B: These combined oral contraceptives (COC)-containing regimens have been approved by the FDA for use as emergency contraception. Pills should be taken within 72 hours. They may be given up to 120 hours but they are effective the sooner they are taken. The combined hormonal regimen consists of two tablets of high-dose norgestrel (250 μg)-ethinyl estradiol (50 μg), repeated 12 hours later and can be given with 50 mg dimenhydrinate initially. 

Option D: Laparoscopic tubectomy is a method of permanent contraception. It is not used as an emergency contraceptive.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: The below depicted sign is seen in which type of melanoma
questions.solution:
The image shows Hutchinsons's nail sign in a subungual melanoma , a variant of Acral lentiginous melanoma. 

Subungual melanoma, a variant of acral lentiginous melanoma, arises from the nail matrix, most commonly in the great toe or thumb

Hutchinson's nail sign is an important clinical clue to subungual melanoma and is characterized by extension of brown or black pigment from the nail bed, matrix, and nail plate to the adjacent cuticle and proximal or lateral nail folds. Also there is associated nail dystrophy.

Remember : 

Acral lentiginous melanoma is type of melanoma  arising on the palms or soles. It is characterised by its site of origin: palm, sole, or beneath the nail (subungual melanoma ).

Other Options : 

Superficial spreading:Form of melanoma in which the malignant cells tend to stay within the tissue of origin, the epidermis, in an ‘in situ ' phase for a prolonged period and then it  grows horizontally on the skin surface – this is known as the radial growth phase. The lesion presents as a slowly-enlarging flat area of discoloured skin.

 

 

 

Nodular melanoma : Here  malignant melanoma cells proliferate downwards through the skin – this is known as vertical growth.

 

 

Lentigo maligna melanoma:Lentigo maligna is an early form of melanoma in which the malignant cells are confined to the tissue of origin, the epidermis, hence it is often reported as 'in situ 'melanoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings suggestive of melanoma

The ABCDE of Melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape.

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill defined.

C : Color variegation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color.

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser).

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)?
questions.solution:
Out of the given conditions, the elevation of BNP is not seen in asthma.

Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) are stored in the atrial and the ventricular myocytes respectively. They are released from these cells when there is distension of the respective chambers because of fluid overload. These peptides cause the excretion of sodium and water by preventing their reabsorption in the renal tubules, and by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). They also cause vasodilation of the systemic arteries.

ANP and BNP thus oppose sodium and water retention in hypervolemic states. However, their actions are not sufficient to prevent edema. Elevated levels of ANP and BNP will be seen in any case when there is fluid overload, such as heart failure (option D) and cirrhosis with ascites (option C).

COPD is characterized by the destruction of the alveolar septa and airway inflammation. Improper gas exchange causes pulmonary vasoconstriction, and over a period of time, there is development of pulmonary hypertension. The right ventricle now has to pump against increased resistance. This leads to decompensation and eventually right heart failure, termed cor pulmonale. Levels of BNP correlate with the severity of right heart dysfunction. 

Other conditions that might be associated with elevated BNP:

  • Myocarditis and cardiomyopathy
  • Valvular heart disease
  • Acute pulmonary embolism (due to right heart failure)
  • Renal insufficiency
  • Hyperaldosteronism

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive drugs is not preferred in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Captopril is an ACE inhibitor, which is contraindicated in pregnancy.

The following drugs are used as antihypertensives in pregnancy:

  1. Labetalol: Given orally 100 mg TID; can be given IV in hypertensive crisis; side effects include tremors, headache, asthma, and congestive cardiac failure.
  2. Methyldopa: Given orally 250 mg BID; may be increased to 1 g QID depending upon the response. Adverse effects include postural hypotension, hemolytic anemia, sodium retention, and excessive sedation in mothers. 
  3. Nifedipine: 5–10 mg TID can be given. Side effects include flushing, hypotension, headache, tachycardia, and inhibition of labor.
  4. Hydralazine: 100 mg/day in four divided doses can be given. Adverse effects include maternal hypotension, tachycardia, arrhythmia, palpitation, lupus-like syndrome, and fluid retention.

ACE inhibitors inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. They should be avoided during pregnancy. Suitable for chronic hypertension in a nonpregnant state or postpartum. When ACE inhibitors are given in the second and third trimesters, they can cause fetal hypotension, renal hypoperfusion, and renal ischemia.

questions.text: An 11-year old boy presented with pain and swelling around his knee. His radiograph is as shown below. Biopsy revealed blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of an 11-year old boy with pain and swelling and radiograph findings showing lytic lesion of the metaphysis of the upper tibia and biopsy showing blood-filled cystic spaces leads to the diagnosis of an aneurysmal bone cyst.

An aneurysmal bone cyst is a benign, expansile lytic lesion of the metaphysis of the long bones comprising blood-filled cystic spaces. It is more common between the age group of 5-20 years with equal male: female distribution. They occur more commonly in the metaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, and humerus. It may occur on the posterior elements of the spine.

Patients usually present with pain and swelling. In cases of spinal involvement, neurologic manifestations can be seen due to nerve root impingement and neurological impairment.

Diagnosis:

A plain radiograph shows an expansile, lytic lesion in the metaphysis. MRI reveals a typical cystic lesion and numerous intralesional septations along with fluid-fluid levels. A biopsy would reveal blood-filled cystic spaces with fibrous septations which might consist of woven bone.

Treatment:

Curettage and bone grafting are done in most cases. Arterial embolization is preferred in cases where curettage is extremely difficult. Low-dose radiation is also effective but avoided in view of potential malignant transformation.

Other options:

Option B- Osteoclastoma (giant cell tumor) is a benign but locally aggressive tumor. It usually affects young adults with a peak incidence in the age group of 20-45 years. A plain radiograph reveals an eccentric, expansile, lobulated lytic lesion in the epiphysis. There is minimal calcification within the tumor. Biopsy reveals osteoclast-like giant cells scattered among round or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. 

Below is the image showing osteoclastoma:

Option C- Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors that present commonly in the adolescent age group. Radiograph and MRI would reveal pedunculated bony protuberance with a stalk (as shown below) or some lesions with a broad sessile base. Histology shows the cap composed of benign hyaline cartilage covered with a perichondrium, disorganised growth plate and endochondral ossification in the stalk and inner portion of the head. 

Option D- Simple bone cyst is a unilocular cystic bone cavity that is filled with serous or serosanguinous fluid. It presents most commonly in the first two decades of life. The most common site is proximal humeral metaphysis most commonly affecting metaphysis close to the physis. On the radiograph, a centrally located, lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline is seen. Histology shows connective tissue lining with foci of reactive bone.

When a fracture occurs, a fragment is seen in the cavity referred to as the fallen fragment sign as shown below:

questions.text:
You are evaluating a 39-year-old male patient for malabsorption and vitamin B12 deficiency. He undergoes a Schilling test and the findings observed are given in the table. What is the likely diagnosis?
Test Absorption
Co-labeled cobalamin Reduced
With intrinsic factor Normal
With pancreatic enzymes Reduced
With Antibiotics for 5 days Reduced
questions.solution:
Normal absorption of Vit B12 with intrinsic factor is seen in Pernicious Anemia.

Pernicious anemia can be defined as a severe lack of intrinsic factor due to gastric atrophy. People who have pernicious anemia can't absorb enough vitamin B12 from food. This is because they lack intrinsic factor, a protein made in the stomach. 

Related Pearl: Schilling Test

The Schilling test is done to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. It involves the administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 followed by the 24-hour collection of urine. The test is then repeated with an additional component that can promote vitamin B12 absorption. If the additional component is able to correct the defect and radiolabeled vitamin B12 is absorbed, it will be detected in the urine.

questions.text: A woman with 6 weeks of amenorrhea had a positive urine pregnancy test. The following finding was seen on transabdominal USG. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given USG image shows an empty gestational sac which is seen in missed abortion before 12 weeks. At this gestational age,  the entire ovum is covered by the chorionic villi giving rise to the empty gestational sac.

If this condition occurs beyond 12 weeks of gestation, a dead fetus is seen on USG. This is not preceded by any warning signs and the fetus is not expelled outside spontaneously.

questions.text: A pregnant woman in labor started bleeding profusely immediately after artificial rupture of membranes and emergency LSCS was performed. The placenta of the patient is given below. Identify the type of placenta.
questions.solution:
The type of placenta shown in the image is the velamentous placenta. The image shows velamentous cord insertion, where the umbilical cord is attached to the fetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

The scenario described is suggestive of vasa previa, in which part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os. The rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels leads to vaginal bleeding and fetal exsanguination.

Other options:

Option A: Battledore placenta: The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.

Option B: Circumvallate placenta - The fetal surface of the placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.

Option D: Succenturiate placenta: One or small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited by :
questions.solution:
Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited by high estrogen.

The synthesis and secretion of milk from the breast alveoli is known as lactogenesis. Prolactin, an anterior pituitary hormone, is responsible for lactogenesis. In spite of high prolactin levels during pregnancy, there is inhibition of milk secretion. This is because of high levels of estrogen and progesterone circulating during pregnancy, which makes the breast tissues unresponsive to prolactin.

Following delivery, there is a fall in estrogen and progesterone levels. As a result, prolactin begins its milk secretory activity in previously fully developed mammary glands.

Other hormones involved in lactogenesis:

  • Insulin
  • Growth hormone
  • Cortisol 
  • Thyroxine
  • Placental lactogen aka human chorionic somatomammotropin: Has growth promoting and lactogenic effects
  • Serotonin

Oxytocin is the major hormone for galactokinesis or the ejection of milk.

questions.text: In tennis elbow, the primary tendinosis occurs at ______.
questions.solution:
In the tennis elbow, primary tendinosis occurs at 1-2 cm distal to the attachment of extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle to the lateral epicondyle. 

Tennis elbow is also known as lateral epicondylitis. This is the most common tendinopathy. It is caused by repetitive contraction of extensor muscles at lateral epicondyle in activities that require repetitive forceful wrist extension and supination. 

It is common in individuals who play tennis, squash, and badminton. The pain improves on rest.

Conservative management with physiotherapy will speed up the recovery. Steroid injections can be used for short-term pain relief. Arthroscopic surgery technique can be used, but it has a higher risk of nerve injury.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus.
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements. 
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension.
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved.

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle. 
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist. 
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in tennis elbow.
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle.

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anaesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative.
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle.

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow.

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases.
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to you with complaints of recurrent swelling of his knees following minor traumas. The mother reports similar symptoms in her brother. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has prolonged partial thromboplastin (PTT) time due to Hemophilia A. 

This patient with a history of recurrent joint swelling on minor trauma with a positive family history on his mother's side and an abnormal coagulation panel raises suspicion for Hemophilia A. This condition is caused due to an X-linked recessive mutation leading to a deficiency of Factor VIII of the coagulation factors. This leads to a prolonged partial thromboplastin time. 

Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder. It occurs due to a deficiency of clotting factor VIII which causes inadequate thrombin generation and thus the inability to form a tight fibrin clot to support the platelet plug.

Symptoms include easy bruising, intramuscular hematomas, hemarthroses, hematuria, and bleeding from minor traumatic lacerations of the mouth can persist for hours or days. Retroperitoneal hemorrhages can accumulate large volumes of blood and may cause a hypovolemic shock.

Laboratory findings in hemophilia A:

  • Factor VIII - reduced
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) - prolonged
  • Platelet count- normal
  • Bleeding time- normal
  • Prothrombin time- normal

A defect in platelet adhesion causes Von Willebrand's disease due to a deficiency of the Von Willebrand factor(VWF). These patients can develop a prolonged PTT as VWF also carries factor VIII so a deficiency of VWF can lead to a relative deficiency of Factor VIII.

Other options:

Option B: Glanzmanns disease is a condition caused by abnormalities of the GpIIBIIIA receptors on platelets and presents with a prolonged bleeding time. It does not cause a prolonged PTT.

Option C: Buerger's disease is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the lower extremities. It is characterized by occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome.

Option D: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is an IgA-mediated hypersensitivity reaction that presents with abdominal pain, palpable purpura, and glomerulonephritis. It does not have a prolonged PTT.

questions.text: A patient was admitted in the morning for shock lithotripsy to a renal stone of 1 cm size. She was considered to be discharged on the same day. All of the following can favour her early discharge except?

choices.text: Adequate pain control from i.v. analgesics
Vitals stable for 60 minutes before the time of discharge

questions.solution:
Adequate pain control from oral analgesics is the criteria for discharge and not i.v. analgesics.

Daycare surgery is defined as the admission and discharge of a patient for a specific procedure within a 12-hour working day. Success in day surgery requires each component of the pathway to be safe and efficient and to be performed in sequence. Unplanned overnight admissions are minimized by ensuring that:

  • the patient is informed and fit for the procedure
  • the procedure itself is achievable as a day case
  • the procedure is scheduled early on the operating list to allow safe recovery and discharge
  • the home environment can support a postoperative ambulatory patient.

Physical fitness for the procedure, short duration, and a home environment that can support recovery and postoperative care are all important factors when choosing daycare surgery for a patient.

Some procedures that qualify for daycare surgery are listed below-

  • Arthroscopies
  • Biopsy (temporal, lymph node)
  • Reducing a strangulated hernia
  • Incision and drainage of an abscess 
  • K-wiring of a finger or wrist bone fracture
  • Laparoscopic appendicectomy

Patient's having daycare surgery can usually be discharged when they have stable vitals, have adequately controlled pain from oral analgesics, can perform basic activities on their own, have no evidence of incision site bleeding, have a designated caregiver, and have all the instructions required for further management at home and instructions in case of an emergency.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic male while undergoing hemodialysis, had a sudden drop in blood pressure and complained of leg cramps. Which of the following is the next best step in the management?

choices.text: Stop hemodialysis and check arterial blood gases
Discontinue ultrafiltration and start saline infusion
Continue hemodialysis and send blood for serum electrolytes
Check serum K+ and arterial blood gases

questions.solution:
The next best step in the management is to discontinue ultrafiltration and start saline infusion.

The clinical features are suggestive of hypotension which is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis. The treatment includes the infusion of saline.

Hypotension occurs due to hypovolemia, caused by excessive removal of fluids. Hypotension can be prevented by careful evaluation of the dry weight and by ultrafiltration modeling, such that more fluid is removed at the beginning rather than the end of the dialysis session. Removal of excess fluid may also cause muscle cramps due to a decrease in muscle perfusion.

The management includes discontinuing ultrafiltration, the administration of 100–250 mL of isotonic saline, or administration of salt-poor albumin.

Related Pearl: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

Based on principle :

Solute removal through a peritoneal membrane

  • Disequilibrium syndrome
  • Muscle cramps
  • Anaphylaxis reaction

Complications :

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances
  • Residual uremia

questions.text: With respect to congenital heart diseases and chest x-rays, which of the following pairs is correct?

choices.text: Transposition of great arteries - egg on side appearance
Tetralogy of Fallot - box shaped heart
Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation - gooseneck sign

questions.solution:
The correct pair is the Transposition of great arteries - egg-on-side appearance or egg-on-string appearance.

In the transposition of great arteries, the heart appears globular (like an egg) due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement. The superior mediastinum appears narrow which gives the appearance of an egg-on-a-string.

questions.text: The following type of nipple discharge is seen in?
questions.solution:
Green nipple discharge as seen in the above image can occur in duct ectasia.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This condition is strongly associated with smoking. The initial stages of this disease consist of the dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with debris. Accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts acts as an irritant and leads to infection and inflammation. This causes periductal mastitis and subsequent fibrosis. If the condition does not resolve, it can lead to the formation of a subareolar mass or abscess. Opening of the abscess onto the skin leads to fistula formation. The persistence of this condition eventually leads to fibrosis, which can cause slit-like retraction of the nipple.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation, which consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts.

Related Pearl: Relative risk of invasive breast carcinoma based on pathological examination of benign breast tissue

No increased risk

  • Adenosis, sclerosing or florid
  • Apocrine metaplasia
  • Cysts, macro and/or micro
  • Duct ectasia
  • Fibroadenoma
  • Fibrosis
  • Hyperplasia
  • Mastitis (inflammation)
  • Periductal mastitis
  • Squamous metaplasia

Slightly increased risk (1.5–2 times)

  • Hyperplasia, moderate or florid, solid, or papillary
  • Papilloma with a fibrovascular core

Moderately increased risk (5 times)

  • Atypical hyperplasia (ductal or lobular)

Insufficient data to assign a risk

  • Solitary papilloma of lactiferous sinus
  • Radial scar lesion

Related Pearl: Discharges from the nipple

  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

    • Intraductal papilloma
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour)
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia

    • Fibrocystic disease

    • Infection
