Remember:

  • The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from single duct is duct papilloma.
  • The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from multiple ducts is duct carcinoma.
  • The most common cause of serous discharge from the breast is fibrocystic disease of breast.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with rapidly growing painful swelling in the angle of the jaw on the right side, with ipsilateral facial palsy. FNAC confirmed mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the parotid gland. She underwent a total radical parotidectomy. Which of the following is the best for nerve grafting in this procedure?
questions.solution:
The best nerve for grafting in total radical parotidectomy is the sural nerve.

In total radical parotidectomy, both the superficial and deep lobes of the parotid and the facial nerve are removed. A cable graft is used to bridge the gap. The commonly used are the interpositional greater auricular nerve and sural nerve (best) grafts.

Surgery:

If only the superficial lobe is involved:

  • superficial parotidectomy- only superficial lobe removed. Usually done in benign conditions.

If both lobes are involved:

  • Total conservative parotidectomy - both lobes are removed but the facial nerve is preserved.
  • Total radical parotidectomy- both lobes and facial nerve removed.

 

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A sexually active male presented with warts on his penis as shown below. Which of these strains of HPV is the most common cause of these lesions?
questions.solution:
Human papillomavirus 6 & 11 (6 >11) are the most common cause of anogenital warts (also known as Condyloma Accuminata).

Giant Anogenital warts are known as Buschke Lowenstein Tumor. It is more common in males than in females.

Most common site:

  • In males: Frenulum, corona, glans penis
  • In females: Posterior fourchette

On histology, koilocytes are seen as shown below.

These are squamous epithelial cells that have nuclear enlargement, irregular nuclear membrane, hyperchromasia, and perinuclear halo.

Most of these warts resolve spontaneously. Persistent warts might transform into malignancy most commonly when infected with HPV 16 and 18.

Treatment:

Provider administered:

  1. Podophyllin (25%) - Antimitotic drug
  2. Trichloroacetic acid
  3. Cryotherapy

Both trichloroacetic acid and cryotherapy are safe in pregnancy.

Patient administered:

  1. Purified podophyllin called podophyllotoxin
  2. Imiquimod - Immunomodulator which acts on toll-like receptors 7 and 8

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with CD4 count < 50/μL complaints of fever, weight loss and night sweats. Which of the following investigations would you order to confirm an atypical mycobacterial infection?

choices.text: Cartridge based nucleic acid amiplification test

questions.solution:
Infection with  Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is confirmed by blood culture. MAC is the atypical Mycobacterium most commonly associated with human disease. MAC is primarily a pulmonary pathogen that affects immune-compromised individuals.

MAC is an atypical mycobacterial infection commonly seen in HIV-infected patients most commonly in those with CD4 count < 50/μL, presenting with fever, weight loss and night sweats. Chest X-ray may show bilateral lower lobe infiltrates, or alveolar infiltrates and mediastinal adenopathy. Diagnosis is made by blood culture or two positive sputum cultures.

As per NACO guidelines, routine prophylaxis is not recommended in India. Therapy for MAC infection is with Clarithromycin or Azithromycin + Ethambutol. 

Other Options:

CBNAAT, IFN-𝛄 assay and BAL may all used to diagnose M. tuberculosis but are not used in the lab diagnosis of MAC. On the other hand, blood culture is not used to diagnose TB.

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker presented with a bright red velvety plaque on the floor of the mouth. A pre-malignant oral lesion is suspected. What is the next best step in the management of the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic smoker presenting with a bright red velvety plaque on the floor of the mouth is suggestive of erythroplakia and the next best step is to do an excision biopsy of the lesion.(Option B)

Erythroplakia is a pre-malignant oral lesion that presents as a bright red velvety patch or plaque commonly at the lower alveolar mucosa, gingivobuccal sulcus and the floor of the mouth. The red colour is due to decreased keratinization and as a result, the red vascular connective tissue of the submucosa shines through. 

Grossly, the lesion may be of three varieties—homogenous, speckled or granular, and erythroplakia, interspersed with areas of leukoplakia. Malignant potential is 17 times higher than in leukoplakia, hence excision biopsy and follow-up are indicated in such cases.

Other options -

Option A) Topical steroids are used to treat oral submucous fibrosis which is another premalignant condition of the oral cavity strongly associated with areca nut and tobacco chewing.  

Option C) Radiotherapy is used as a primary modality in the treatment of Stage 2(T2N0M0) carcinoma of buccal mucosa and tongue. T2 refers to the size of tumor - 2 to 4cm. It is also used as an adjuvant therapy post-surgery in stages 3 and 4 of carcinoma of the oral cavity.

Option D) Laser ablation or cryotherapy can be done in small lesions of leukoplakia provided biopsy ruled out malignancy.

questions.text: Artificial insemination is least likely to be useful in _______.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with infertility underwent semen analysis. Results show a sperm concentration of 18 million/ml, pH- 7.5, and volume- 2 ml. No agglutination is seen. Morphology shows 10% normal forms and 20% motile sperms. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given semen analysis point towards a diagnosis of asthenospermia as only 20% of the sperms are motile. Normally, 32% of sperm should be motile.

Other options:

Option A: Azoospermia - Absence of sperm in semen

Option C: Normospermia - Sperm concentration of > 15 million/ml

Option D: Oligospermia- Sperm concentration of < 15 million/ml 

Note: 

Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding renal cell carcinoma is true?

choices.text: It is more common in women
It is associated with right sided varicocele in men
Hematuria is the most common presenting symptom

questions.solution:
The true statement is- Hematuria is the most common presenting symptom.

Hypernephroma / Grawitz tumor/ Adenocarcinoma of the kidney

  • It is the most common neoplasm of the kidney (75%)
  • Hematuria is the most common presentation, may be associated with clot colic
  • M: F= 4:1
  • Left-sided varicocele is seen in men because the left gonadal vein is obstructed where it joins the left renal vein.
  • CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • Nephrectomy is the treatment of choice. It is poorly responsive to radiotherapy or chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

Clear-cell Type

  • Most common type
  • Originate from proximal tubule
  • Associated with von Hippel–Lindau (VHL) disease

Papillary Type

  • Psammoma bodies are seen in histology
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules, can be multifocal and bilateral.

  • Are unique in having multiple losses of entire chromosomes
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Good prognosis

  • Poor prognosis

Renal medullary carcinoma

  • Rare 
  • Associated with sickle cell trait
  • Originates from collecting duct

Note:

Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the lab criteria for diagnosis of APLA syndrome?
questions.solution:
Raised aPTT is not a lab criterion for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome. 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that is commonly associated with fetal death, preterm delivery, early-onset preeclampsia, and fetal growth restriction due to placental insufficiency and thromboses. Pregnancy loss usually occurs before 10 weeks.

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical criterion and 1 laboratory criterion.

  • Obstetric criteria
    • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks, or
    • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
    • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
  • Laboratory criteria
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL), also referred to as a recurrent miscarriage or habitual abortion, is historically defined as 3 consecutive pregnancy losses before 20 weeks from the last menstrual period. 

Note: The new 2023 ACR/EULAR criteria, is an update from the revised Sapporo criteria with the clinical criteria divided into 6 domains and each metric in the clinical and laboratory value adding a weighted score. This has increased the specificity in diagnosing APS.

questions.text: A 4 day old baby is active and feeding well. He has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of the baby?
questions.solution:
Since this child has a bilirubin level of only 8 mg/dl on the 4th day, it points to physiologic jaundice. The child is active and feeding well, the mother should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding frequently and exclusively.

All the other options would be possible treatment choices if the child had pathological jaundice. 

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd days usually peaks on the 4th day at 5-6 mg/dL and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth. 

On the other hand, in pathological jaundice, appearance is within the first 24 hours after birth and may be present at or beyond the age of 2 weeks in term babies and 3 weeks in preterm babies. There may be an elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level. Jaundice visible on the palms and soles, unresponsiveness to phototherapy, and a rapid rise in bilirubin levels during phototherapy indicate pathological jaundice.

Phototherapy is initiated in babies with pathological jaundice when the bilirubin levels exceed the 95th percentile on the total serum bilirubin (TSB) normogram. Babies are kept at a distance of 30-45 cm from the UV lamp (460-490 nm) with eyes and gonads covered. It is avoided in babies with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to the risk of bronze-baby syndrome. Dehydration and hypocalcemia are potential complications and breastfeeding is encouraged.

Exchange transfusion (ET) is done in cases of bilirubin encephalopathy, Rh incompatibility with significant hemolysis, and bilirubin values exceeding TSB cutoffs for ET.

Note: Phototherapy acts mainly by structural isomerization. Phototherapy is effective only when there is bilirubin in the skin. So, there is no role of prophylactic phototherapy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube?
questions.solution:
The best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube is the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography. 

Capnography is a non-invasive method of measurement and graphical display of partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled breath or the end-tidal CO2. Capnograph is the device used for measurement and capnogram is the CO2 waveform that is displayed. It is the most reliable indicator of endotracheal tube placement.

The proper placement of the endotracheal tube is indicated by a normal CO2 waveform for at least three breaths.

Other signs to confirm proper endotracheal intubation are symmetrical chest rise, presence of equal bilateral breath sounds, absent breath sounds over the epigastrium, visible condensation in the ETT, large exhaled tidal volume and appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation.

Absent CO2 waveform tracing despite correct ETT intubation is seen in the following conditions:

  • Severe bronchospasm,
  • Equipment malfunction,
  • Cardiac arrest, or hemodynamic collapse 

Clinical relevance:

  • Capnography does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation. Signs of endobronchial intubation include increased peak expiratory pressure, hypoxemia, increased airway pressures, asymmetric chest expansion and the absence of breath sounds over one lung, generally the left.  
  • In esophageal intubation, the capnograph can initially detect some CO2 in the stomach from swallowing expired air. But after a few breaths, this CO2  will be washed out and ETCO2 will become zero. 
  • The most sensitive and earliest indicator of malignant hyperthermia is a persistent increase in ETCO2.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents with a painless testicular mass with a sense of heaviness in the scrotum. His blood work showed raised LDH and AFP. Which of the following is the next diagnostic investigation?

LDH - Lactate dehydrogenase.

AFP - α-fetoprotein.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a middle-aged man presenting with a painless testicular mass with a sense of heaviness in the scrotum suggests the diagnosis of a testicular tumour. Blood work showed raised LDH and AFP which are tumour markers for non-seminomatous germ cell tumours (NSGCTs). The diagnostic investigation of choice is ultrasonography.

Testicular tumours are uncommon male malignancies. Seminomas generally occur in the 4th decade of life, while NSGCTs are common in the 3rd decade of life. Spermatocytic seminomas occur commonly in men older than 50 years. WHO classification of testicular tumours is given below.

Clinical features of testicular tumours are:

  • Occurrence in the specific age group.
  • Painless testicular mass is the usual symptom
  • Sense of scrotal heaviness
  • Abdominal or lumbar mass due to metastasis
  • Chest pain, dyspnea, and haemoptysis due to lung metastasis
  • Prepubertal interstitial cell tumours produce androgens, causing precocious puberty
  • Postpubertal interstitial cell tumours produce feminising hormones, leading to gynecomastia, erectile dysfunction, loss of libido and azoospermia.

The diagnostic investigation of choice is ultrasonography (USG). USG of the affected as well as the unaffected testis is done and is mandatory. Tumour markers aid in the diagnosis. Chest X-ray is done to detect 'cannon ball' metastasis in the lungs.

Other options:

Option A - Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) is done to assess the thoracic, abdominal and pelvic areas for metastasis. Although it is essential in staging and monitoring response to therapy it is not the diagnostic investigation of choice.

Option C: Trans-scrotal biopsy has no role in the diagnosis of testicular tumours.

Option D: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) may be used as an adjunct if ultrasound findings are equivocal, or if the location of the mass is uncertain.

questions.text:
Match the correct answer related to the nerve injuries in various surgeries
  1. Breast surgery
  2. Thyroid surgery
  3. Submandibular excision
  4. Thymectomy
  1. Long Thoracic Nerve
  2. External Laryngeal nerve
  3. Hypoglossal nerve
  4. Vagus nerve
questions.solution:
A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4 is the correct option.

During breast surgery, removal of axillary lymph nodes is common. This carries a risk of injury to long thoracic nerve, which originates from C5-C7 roots of brachial plexus. It innervates serratus anterior muscle.

Injury to this nerve during surgery results in paralysis of serratus anterior muscle leading to winging of the scapula.

The external laryngeal nerve is a motor nerve that supplies the cricothyroid muscle. The close relationship of the external laryngeal nerve to the superior thyroid artery puts the nerve at potential risk when the artery is clamped during thyroid surgeries.

Excision of submandibular gland results in potential risk to 3 cranial nerves,

  • Marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve;
  • Lingual nerve;
  • Hypoglossal nerve.

Vagus nerve is at greater risk of injury during surgeries like Thymectomy.

questions.text: A 61-year-old hypertensive male patient presents with back pain. He has been smoking for the past 30 years. On physical exam, he has an enlarged pulsatile mass over his abdomen. His CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is an indication for elective surgical repair in this patient?

choices.text: Presence of a pulsatile mass on physical exam

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describing a smoker with abdominal/back pain, history of hypertension and smoking, physical examination revealing a pulsatile mass, and CT findings showing dilation of the abdominal aorta is indicative of abdominal aortic aneurysm(AAA). Abdominal aortic aneurysm ≥5.5 cm is an indication for elective surgical repair of AAA. 

The following are indications for elective surgical repair of AAA:

  1. Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm ≥5.5 cm
  2. Rapid expansion >1 cm in 1 year.
  3. Symptomatic patients/ patients with a ruptured aneurysm
  4. AAA associated with peripheral arterial aneurysm (eg, iliac, popliteal) or symptomatic peripheral artery disease (eg, iliac occlusive disease) undergoing revascularization


Surgical options for the repair of aortic aneurysms are endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) and open aneurysm repair. EVAR is preferred over open aneurysm repair in current practice.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is the most common type of large vessel aneurysm. The most important risk factor to develop AAA is atherosclerosis. In the majority of cases, it occurs below the renal arteries.

Risk factors for AAA are age, male sex, atherosclerosis, smoking history, hypertension, and connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

The patients may be asymptomatic or may present with symptoms of abdominal pain or back pain. They might have a pulsatile abdominal mass on palpation. The patients are hemodynamically stable in case of an intact aneurysm. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm should be suspected in a patient with the triad of severe abdominal/back pain, hypotension, and a pulsatile abdominal mass. Lower limb ischemia may be present in advanced cases.

It is diagnosed by ultrasonography, which is the screening modality of choice. CT scan is the gold standard for determining the anatomic eligibility for endovascular repair.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby who accidentally put a tiny plastic ball in his mouth suddenly developed a violent cough, wheezing, and dyspnea. The baby is conscious and while you attempted back slaps on the baby, he lost consciousness. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Continue back slap till foreign body dislodges

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of cough, wheezing and dyspnea following accidental ingestion of a plastic piece is suggestive of a foreign body airway obstruction(choking). As the child becomes unconscious after giving back slaps, the next step is to perform chest compressions.

Back slaps are given by placing the infant's torso on the rescuer's nondominant arm or draping an older child across the knees. They are given between the shoulder blades using the heel of the rescuer’s hand. In the case of choking, 5 back slaps and 5 chest thrusts are given alternatively.

Chest thrusts are given by putting the patient supine, and the rescuer should kneel close to the victim’s side. Hands are placed in the same manner as is done to perform CPR chest compressions. Each thrust is given in such a way as to relieve the obstruction. 

The images below depict back slaps and chest thrusts respectively.

 

If the child becomes unresponsive after performing back slaps and chest thrusts, then chest compressions should be started immediately after stopping back slaps and chest thrusts(option D).

Other options

Option A: Heimlich manoeuvre is contraindicated in children less than 1 year.

Option C: While performing back slaps if the child becomes unresponsive it is not advised to perform rescue breaths. An attempt to provide two rescue breaths can be provided after the healthcare provider provides 30 compressions with reassessment of the airway.

questions.text: Therapeutic Hypothermia is indicated in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic Hypothermia is indicated in the treatment of Hypoxic Ischaemic Encephalopathy (HIE)

HIE is a form of brain injury that occurs due to inadequate blood flow to the infant’s brain occurring as a result of a hypoxic-ischemic event during the prenatal, intrapartum, or postnatal period. This causes the accumulation of toxic metabolites and depletion of intra-cellular energy that further leads to neuronal injury and death.

Therapeutic Hypothermia involves systemic cooling to achieve a core temperature of 33.5°C within the first 6 hours after birth, for a period of 72 hours. This causes a reduction in the rate of production of toxic compounds and reduces seizure activity, thereby favoring cerebro-protection, especially in HIE due to intrapartum insult. It has been shown to reduce mortality and neuro-development impairment. In adults, therapeutic hypothermia also has a role in the treatment of cardiac arrest to prevent global cerebral ischemia.

The clinical grading is based on Sarnat & Sarnat Staging and HIE is described in three stages as shown below.

Signs Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3
Level of consciousness Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose
Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid
Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate
Tendon reflex/clonus Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent
Myoclonus Present Present Absent
Moro reflex Strong Weak Absent
Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal, poor light reflex
Seizures None Common Decerebration
EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to seizure activity Burst suppression to isoelectric
Duration <24 hours if progress; otherwise, may remain normal 24 hours to 14 days Days to weeks
Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits    

Infants at >36 weeks of gestation with one out of the following four criteria, and in Sarnat Stage 2 or 3 encephalopathies, may be started on therapeutic hypothermia

  • APGAR scores <5 at 10 minutes.
  • Positive pressure ventilation is required at ten minutes
  • Umbilical cord pH or any arterial pH <7, within 1 hour of life
  • Base deficit of more than 16 mmol/L in cord blood or arterial blood within 1 hour of life

Other Options:

Option B: Febrile seizures are managed with anticonvulsants like lorazepam and midazolam. Antipyretics may be used to decrease the child's discomfort but do not treat seizures.

Option C: Malignant Hyperthermia is an anesthetic complication and is managed using IV Dantrolene Sodium in sterile water. The use of ice packs for lowering the body temperature is indicated but only up to normal body temperature, and not to induce hypothermia.

Option D: Neonatal hyperthermia may occur when an infant is exposed to high temperatures (radiant warmer, phototherapy) for prolonged periods. It is managed by removing the infant from the source of heat, followed by cooling in a bath to the normal body temperature. Hypothermia or cooling devices are not indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association with hormone replacement therapy?
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy decreases the risk of colon cancer.

Indications of HRT:

  • Therapeutic
    • Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency
    • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • Prophylactic
    • High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis(Option D), stroke, Alzheimer’s disease, and colonic cancer
    • Premature menopause, spontaneous or following surgery 
    • Menopause caused by radiotherapy and chemotherapy for cancer, especially alkylating agents 
    • Women demanding HRT as prophylaxis

Contraindications of HRT:

  • Undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
  • Known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasia
  • Active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • Active or recent (e.g., within the past year) arterial thromboembolic disease
  • Liver dysfunction or gallbladder disease
  • Known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the estrogen preparation
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine fibroids as the fibroids may enlarge in size.

Uses of HRT:

  • Short term-hot flushes, vasomotor symptoms
  • Dyspareunia, libido
  • Urethral syndrome
  • Long term-osteoporosis
  • Cardiovascular disease
  • Alzheimer’s disease

Risks of HRT:

  • Endometrial cancer(Option C)
  • Breast cancer(Option B)
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Thromboembolism
  • Lipid profile dysfunction
  • Gall stones, liver dysfunction

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with the following deformity. She complains of joint pain and stiffness in the fingers for 5-6 years. She reports that stiffness is more in the early morning and improves on performing household activities. What is the most common extra-articular manifestation seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with image showing swan neck deformity (hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint) is classically seen in rheumatoid arthritis. The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis is subcutaneous nodules. 

Subcutaneous nodules are generally firm, non-tender nodules that are adherent to the periosteum, tendons, or bursae. They develop in areas that are subjected to repeated trauma or irritation such as the forearm, sacral prominences, and Achilles tendon. Nodules can also develop in the lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum. Infection, gangrene and malignant transformation can be rarely seen with subcutaneous nodules.

Other extraarticular manifestations seen in rheumatoid arthritis are:

  • Sjogren syndrome - it presents with keratoconjunctivitis sicca or xerostomia
  • Rheumatoid vasculitis - it presents as petechiae, purpura, digital infarcts, gangrene, livedo reticularis
  • Pulmonary -  
    • Pleuritis - most common pulmonary manifestation
    • Interstitial lung diseases
  • Cardiac - 
    • Pericarditis - most common cardiac manifestation
    • Cardiomyopathy
    • Mitral regurgitation
    • Coronary artery disease
  • Hematologic - 
    • Normochromic normocytic anemia - most common hematologic abnormality 
    • Felty's syndrome - is a triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly, and nodular rheumatoid arthritis. It is a rare manifestation
    • Lymphoma

Patients developing extra-articular manifestations are associated with risk factors such as: History of smoking, early onset of physical disability, rheumatoid factor positive and anti-CCP antibody positive.

Related Pearl: Most commons conditions in Rheumatoid Arthritis

M/C extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules
M/C pulmonary manifestation Pleuritis
M/C cardiac involvement Pericarditis
M/C valvular lesion Mitral regurgitation
M/C hematologic abnormality Normochromic, normocytic anemia
M/C part of the spine involved Cervical spine
M/C type of lymphoma Diffuse large B cell lymphoma
M/C cause of death Cardiovascular disease

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

NSAIDs - Analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive agents for the management of uncontrollable symptoms and useful in an acute flare.

Glucocorticoids - Used during an acute flare for rapid disease control and as initial therapy before the onset of the effect of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed to control disease in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone- oral 
  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     
DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs

Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX): It is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine: It used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine: A salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide: A pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

 

Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists: Used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept: A T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab: An anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra: An IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with an anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists: Tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

 

Small molecules: Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, barcitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: At what age of gestation is an amniocentesis generally done?
questions.solution:
The best time for performing amniocentesis is 15-20 weeks of gestation

Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure. It is performed using an aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle. The needle is directed perpendicularly into a clear pocket of amniotic fluid while avoiding the fetus and umbilical cord. Sonography is used to observe the uterine puncture site for bleeding and fetal cardiac motion is documented at the end of the procedure. Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping or chromosomal microarray analysis. 

Study material

Amniotic fluid with amniocytes

Time

15-20 weeks

Early amniocentesis

11-14 weeks (associated with increased fetal loss, foot deformities)

Indications
  • Congenital infections
  • Fetal genetic disorders
  • Alloimmunization
  • Assessment of lung maturity
Complications
  • Fetal loss
  • Amniotic fluid lekagae
  • Transvaginal spotting

Below is an image showing the procedure of amniocentesis vs chorionic villus sampling.

 

Note:

Amniocentesis is generally done between 15-20 weeks but may be performed at any point later in gestation.

Related Pearl: Prenatal diagnostic procedures

Materials for study Trophoblast cells Fetal  fibroblasts fluid for biochemical study 

Fetal white blood cells by puncturing the umbilical vein

(others—infection and biochemical study)
Karyotype result Direct preparation: 24–48 hours.Culture: 10–14 days Culture:3–4 weeks   Culture:24–48 hours
Fetal loss 0.5–1% 0.5%  1–2%

questions.text: A middle-aged man came to the casualty with a history of pelvic trauma following a road traffic accident. You are asked to apply a pelvic binder to this patient. At what level is the pelvic binder applied?
questions.solution:
The pelvic binder should be applied at the level of greater trochanters of the hip.

The pelvic binder is routinely used as the initial management of pelvic injuries especially if associated with polytrauma, external bleeding, or hemodynamic instability. The use of a pelvic binder has almost eliminated the use of external fixators on the pelvis.

The pelvic binder acts by closing the pelvis volume and thereby providing temporary hemodynamic stability to the patient. Nonetheless, further assessment through radiological investigations such as x-ray pelvis AP view and CT pelvis 3-D reconstruction is important for further definitive management of pelvic injuries.

Ideally binders should not be left for more than 24 hours in view of pressure sores , but if there is no availability of an emergency facility to stabilize the hemodynamic compromise then it can be momentarily released to check for pressure sores and then reapplied if necessary. During radiological assessments like X-ray or CT scan, the pelvic binder is released after positioning the patient in order to assess the extent of pelvic injury as the pelvic binder might falsely underestimate the severity of the injury.

questions.text: A father brings his child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding. He has been on a diet consisting mainly of rice water, after being exclusively breastfed till the age of 8 months. Laboratory investigations show markedly low serum albumin levels. Which of the following findings are not consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding with low serum protein and albumin is suggestive of kwashiorkor, where simian facies is not seen. Simian facies is consistent with marasmus.

Kwashiorkor is a clinical syndrome seen in severe acute malnutrition (SAM). It is associated with pitting edema and apathy and affects children aged 1-4 years.

Edema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs soon developing into generalized edema. Abdominal distension occurs with or without dilated bowel loops and hepatomegaly with fatty infiltrate.

Skin changes occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled peeling patches with pale skin underneath forming patches of hyper and hypopigmentation called flaky paint dermatosis or crazy paving. The skin gets easily infected.

The image given below shows flaky paint dermatosis seen in kwashiorkor.

The hair is dull, brittle, sparse, and can easily be pulled out. It may lose its curl. Alternating bands of light and normal color hair may be seen, known as the flag sign. Children are miserable, apathetic, and often refuse to eat. There is marked muscle atrophy and growth retardation.

The management of protein-energy malnutrition (PEM) is outlined in the image below.

  1. Alert

  3. Baggy pant appearance

Special features:

The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the Bandl ring seen?
questions.solution:
Bandl ring is a pathological retraction ring seen in obstructed labour.

Bandl ring/Retraction ring

  • In obstructed labour, the upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigorously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.
  • With each contraction, there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.
  • The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring/Bandl ring.

Other options:

Constriction ring/Schroeder's ring

  • It is formed due to incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus.
  • It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes.

Related Pearl: Constriction ring v/s retraction ring in uterus

  Constriction / Schroeder's ring  Retraction/ Bandl's ring
Nature Due to incoordinate uterine contraction Due to tonic uterine contractions and retractions
Cause Undue irritability of uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin Obstructed labor
Location

Usually at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Location does not alter once formed.

Always at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.
Per abdomen Ring not felt Ring is felt
Per Vaginal Ring is felt Ring not felt

questions.text: A young adult met with a minor bike accident. There are no obvious external injuries. However, the handle-bar has hit hard on his upper abdomen. His vitals are stable. If we suspect a pancreaticoduodenal injury, Which is the modality of choice to investigate this?
questions.solution:
The modality of choice for the evaluation of patients with abdominal trauma is computed tomography (CT) scanning of the abdomen.

Pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ. Hence, Ultrasound (Option A) is not a good imaging modality.

Option B: Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatogrphy is a diagnostic as well as well as a therapeutic option. It is an invasive method. ERCP can be used for pancreatic stenting after the non invasive methods(CT and MRCP) has delineated the anatomy and graded the injury. 

Option C: Isolated serum amylase (Option D)measurement is not recommended because up to 40% of patients with transected pancreatic duct have normal serum amylase levels.

Isolated pancreatic injuries are not common. Up to 90% of patients present with associated hepatic, gastric, splenic, renal, colonic, or vascular lesions.

questions.text:
An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Hb - 6.9g/dL
  • WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count
  • Serum calcium 13mg/dL
  • Creatinine 2.3mg/dL
  • Total protein 9g/dL
  • Albumin 2.4g/dL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes an elderly woman with confusion, thirst and abdominal pain along with elevated serum calcium levels (hypercalcemia), elevated creatinine suggestive of renal failure, anemia and osteolytic bone lesions (CRAB features); and hypoalbuminemia with elevated total proteins. The most likely diagnosis is multiple myeloma (MM).

Multiple myeloma (MM) is a malignant plasma cell disorder characterized by clonal plasma cell proliferation, increased osteoclast activity, and suppressed osteoblast activity, leading to bone lesions and hypercalcemia. Common signs include bone pain, fractures, infections, anemia, elevated ESR, and normal ALP.

Diagnosis involves finding monoclonal immunoglobulin (M spike) on electrophoresis, Bence Jones proteins in urine, and rouleaux formation on a peripheral smear. MM is diagnosed based on ≥10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow or biopsy-proven plasmacytoma, along with myeloma-defining CRAB features (hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, anemia, or bone lesions).

Treatment includes a combination of lenalidomide/thalidomide (immunomodulatory agents), bortezomib (proteasome inhibitor), and dexamethasone. International Staging System (ISS) is used for assessing prognosis in multiple myeloma patients. Serum β2-microglobulin is the most important prognostic marker.

Other options:

Option A: The bony metastasis in breast carcinoma is usually osteolytic. However, CRAB features, hypoalbuminemia, and elevated total protein suggest multiple myeloma.

Option C: Primary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by hypercalcemia and low phosphorus but is not associated with anemia and hypoalbuminemia.

Option D: Milk-alkali syndrome occurs after ingestion of large amounts of calcium and vitamin D supplementation. It results in hypercalcemia, alkalosis, nephrocalcinosis, and nephrolithiasis.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

Raised [PTH]

Decreased [PTH]

Hyperparathyroidism

  • Primary (adenoma > hyperplasia)
  • Secondary
  • Tertiary

Hypercalcemia of malignancy

Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

Vitamin D toxicity

 

Immobilization

 

Thiazide diuretics

 

Sarcoidosis

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

Plasma cell neoplasms and variants

Plasma cell myeloma
  • Non secretory: No secretion of Ig, No M component.
  • Smoldering: M protein in serum ≥ 3g/dL and/or ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow, and no related organ or tissue impairment.
  • Plasma-cell leukemia: >20% plasma cells in the peripheral blood or Absolute plasma cell count of >2 X 109/L.

Plasmacytoma
  • Solitary plasmacytoma: Localized tumour of monoclonal plasma cells with no clinical features of plasma cell myeloma.
  • Extramedullary(extraosseous) plasmacytoma: Localized plasma cell neoplasms that arise in tissues other than bone.

Monoclonal immunoglobulin deposition diseases
  • Primary amyloidosis: Tumor secreting light chains that are deposited as beta-pleated sheet structure (amyloid light chain).
  • Systemic light and heavy chain diseases: Secrete abnormal light or heavy chain or both, which do not form beta pleated sheet, stain Congo Red or contain amyloid P component.

Plasma cell neoplasms with associated paraneoplastic syndrome

POEMS syndrome- Polyneuropathy, organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal gammopathy, Skin changes.

TEMPI syndrome

questions.text: As an intern posted in a PHC, you observe a public water tank disinfected with chlorine. Following this, an orthotolidine-arsenite test is performed. What is/are the parameters measured by this test?
questions.solution:
The parameters measured by the orthotolidine-arsenite test (OTA) are free and combined chlorine separately.

It is a modification of the orthotolidine test (OT), that measures free and combined chlorine levels together. (Option C)

In addition, the errors caused by the presence of interfering substances such as nitrites, iron and manganese, that produce yellow colour(positive)with an OT test are overcome by the OTA test.

The OT test is performed by adding 0.1 ml of the reagent containing orthotoludine dissolved in 10% hydrochloric acid to 1 ml of water to be tested. A yellow colour is produced which is matched against suitable standards or colour discs. Commercial equipment is available for this purpose. It is essential to take the reading within 10 seconds after the addition of the reagent to estimate free chlorine in water. The colour that is produced after a lapse of 15-20 minutes, is due to the action of both free and combined chlorine.

The chlorine demand is measured by Horrock’s apparatus. (Option A)

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for large scale purification of water and for drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • Alongside its anti-pathogenic attributes, it oxidizes iron, manganese and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odor producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • Action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    • Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water which contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorines.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors caused due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorines separately.

questions.text: According to DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs, uterosacral ligaments belong to which level of pelvic support?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey, the uterosacral ligaments and cardinal ligaments belong to level 1.

This dense visceral connective tissue complex maintains the vaginal length and horizontal axis. It allows the vagina to be supported by the levator plate and positions the cervix just superior to the level of the ischial spines. Defects in this support complex may lead to apical prolapse.

Level I support suspends the proximal vagina. Level II support attaches the midvagina along its length to the arcus tendineus fascia. Level III support results from the fusion of the distal vagina with adjacent structures. 

Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle. Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent. 

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Supports of the Uterus

    • Perineal body

  • Ligamentous (Fibromuscular or Mechanical) Support

    • Uterosacral ligament

    • Pubocervical ligament
    • Uterine axis

B. Secondary Supports formed by Peritoneal Ligaments

  • Broad ligament
  • Uterovesical fold of peritoneum
  • Rectovaginal fold of peritoneum

questions.text: A young man is incidentally found to have a pseudocyst of the pancreas on abdominal ultrasound. Past history is notable for one episode of acute pancreatitis. An aspirate from the cyst is likely to show:

choices.text: Low amylase levels and high carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
Low amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
High amylase levels and high carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
High amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels

questions.solution:
An aspirate from a pancreatic pseudocyst is likely to show high amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels. It is also associated with the absence of mucin.

Pancreatic pseudocysts are non-necrotic fluid-filled oval or round collections encapsulated in a relatively thick wall. They develop 4 weeks after acute pancreatitis and are frequently found on imaging follow-up of pancreatitis. They may be asymptomatic or become large enough to cause mass effects such as gastric outlet obstruction, bowel obstruction, hydronephrosis, and biliary obstruction.

The capsule of a pseudocyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. It presents with abdominal pain and epigastric mass. CT is usually done in the evaluation of pancreatic pseudocysts.

Observation is the preferred treatment in cases where the size of the pseudocyst is less than 6 cm and arises from the tail of the pancreas. Interventions are required when it is complicated with infection, large size causing mass effect, diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm, recurrence following previous resection.

Treatment includes:

  • Open surgical debridement
  • Cystenterostomy
  • Endoscopic cyst-gastrostomy
  • Percutaneous drainage
  • Octreotide infusion (decreases the amount of pancreatic secretions)

Based on the revised Atlanta classification, peripancreatic fluid, and their collections can be classified into 4 different types based on their morphology and time of presentation:

  • Interstitial edematous pancreatitis (IEP):
    • APFC- acute peripancreatic fluid collection. Non-necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks 
    • Pancreatic pseudocyst- non-necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)
  • Necrotizing pancreatitis:
    • ANC- acute necrotic collection. Necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks 
    • WON- walled-off necrosis. Necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)

Collections that contain non-liquefied material or show the presence of gas, are more likely to be infected.

Note: High levels of CEA is suggestive of mucinous neoplasm.

Related Pearl: Cystic Neoplasm of the Pancreas

Usual site

Stains positive for estrogen and progesterone

questions.text: In a family planning clinic, you see a flyer advertising the pills shown below as a method of contraception. Identify the true statement about it.

choices.text: Can be taken by diabetic women

questions.solution:
The true statement about desogestrel pills (synthetic progesterone-only pills) is that they can be taken by diabetic women. This is because they have minimal effects on carbohydrate metabolism.

Progesterone-only pills are also known as minipills. They are started 21 days postpartum and soon after an abortion. The woman needs to take precautions in the first 48 hours of the first cycle.

The mechanism of action of progesterone-only pills involves thickening of the cervical mucus that inhibits penetration of sperms (mainly), atrophy of the endometrium, and inhibition of ovulation.

Advantages of progesterone-only pills include:

  • Minimal or no effects on carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
  • Do not cause or exacerbate hypertension 
  • Do not impair milk production, therefore suitable during lactation
  • Safe for women with a history of migraine headaches
  • Safe for smokers who are older than 35 years

Contraindications include abnormal uterine bleeding, breast cancer, hepatic cancer, pregnancy, and active severe liver disease. Additionally, synthetic progestogens like desogestrel are associated with a higher incidence of thromboembolism.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: According to DSM V, to diagnose a child with dysthymia, symptoms of depression should be present over a period of at least _________
questions.solution:
In children and adolescents, symptoms of depression should be present over a period of at least 1 year to diagnose dysthymia (in adults - 2years).

DSM V Criteria for diagnosis of dysthymia

Depressed mood for most of the day as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years. In children and adolescents - at least 1 year.

Presence of two (or more) of the following while being depressed.

  • Poor appetite or overeating
  • Insomnia or hypersomnia
  • Low energy or fatigue
  • Low self-esteem
  • Poor concentration and/or difficulty making decisions
  • Feelings of hopelessness

questions.text: You are a resident doctor who is attending to a patient brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. He has an open fracture of the tibia, his limbs are cold and clammy and his BP is 90/50 mmHg, and pulse 130 beats/min. You start the patient on IV Plasma-Lyte. The true statement about this IV fluid is that:

choices.text: It is an isotonic electrolyte preparation
It does not have buffer action

questions.solution:
The true statement about Plasma-Lyte is that it is a crystalloid fluid with isotonic electrolyte composition.

The type of fluid administered to a patient depends on his/her volume status and the type of compositional abnormality present. Plasma- Lyte is isotonic and is useful in replacing gastrointestinal losses and correcting extracellular volume deficits.

Plasma-Lyte is an isotonic crystalloid preparation; it resembles the electrolyte composition of the human plasma very closely. In addition, Plasma- Lyte contains a number of additional buffers that create a favourable profile for helping with acidosis.

It consists of 140 mEq/L of sodium, 98 mEq/L of chloride, 5 mEq/L of potassium, 27 mEq/L of bicarbonate and 3 mEq/L of Magnesium.

These properties have resulted in Plasma-Lyte becoming one of the most popular isotonic fluids for use, especially in surgery. However, Plasma- Lyte contains small quantities of potassium; and though the likelihood of inducing hyperkalemia is very low, care should be taken when using Plasma-Lyte in patients at risk for renal impairment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient after hysterectomy complains of urine dribbling from the vagina. On examination, vesicovaginal fistula is observed. Which technique of fistula repair is suitable in this case?
questions.solution:
The preferred technique of repair of the vesicovaginal fistula which occurred post-hysterectomy is Latzko's procedure.

Latzko's procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges, freshening the edges, and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by cancer cervix. It can lead to narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia.

Fistula located at the vaginal vault post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat, this technique is suited for such cases.

In the case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken.

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired vaginally.

The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chasser Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation

Other options:

Option A: Chassar Moir technique widely separated the vagina and bladder all around by the flap-splitting method and suturing the bladder and vagina separately into two. It has the advantage of tension-free sutures and avoidance of the superior position of the bladder over the vaginal suture. 

Option C: Ureteric implantation is considered in cases with extensive loss of bladder tissue, or repetitive failures to close the fistula. Here ureters are implanted into the sigmoid colon creating an ileal loop bladder, or rectal bladder. The disadvantage of this procedure is the high incidence of ascending infection to the kidneys and the risk of electrolyte imbalance.

Option D: Kelly's repair is the anterior colporrhaphy with bladder neck plication done for stress urinary incontinence.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology Mostly obstetric causes mostly gynecological surgeries
Clinical Continuous dribbling of urine—no micturition Continuous dribbling of urine but can also micturate
Methylene swab test Swab stains with methylene blue   Swab stains with urine—but not with methylene blue
IVP Normal Hydronephrosis presents on the affected side

The methylene blue 3 swab test:

Procedure:

A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle and one just above the introitus.

50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Results:

  • Uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula

questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with edema and anasarca. A diagnosis of minimal change disease is made. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes

questions.solution:
The true statement about minimal change disease is that it shows a good response to steroids. 

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. It is more common in males and appears between 2 to 6 years of age.

The causes of MCD are mostly idiopathic. It is usually associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma (due to the increased production of cytokines), respiratory infections, prophylactic immunizations, eczema, and rhinitis.

Clinically, they mostly present with proteinuria. The child presents with a history of edema that is initially noted around the eyes and gradually progresses into generalized edema. Hypertension and hematuria are uncommon.

Levels of the following proteins are increased in nephrotic syndrome:

  • Fibrinogen - leads to hypercoagulability.
  • Lipoproteins - due to increased synthesis.

Levels of the following proteins are decreased in nephrotic syndrome as a consequence of selective proteinuria:

  • Albumin—the protein with the largest proportion of loss in nephrotic syndrome
  • Transferrin
  • Cholecalciferol-binding protein
  • Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)
  • Ferritin
  • Coagulation factors 
  • Antithrombin III

Diagnosis can be made by urinalysis showing proteinuria, ranging from 3+ to 4+ protein on urine dipstick and a spot urine protein/creatinine ratio (PCR) >2. The proteinuria principally contains albumin, hence known as selective proteinuria. Serum albumin levels are <2.5 g/dL and there is an increase in serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels. 

Biopsy findings include the following: 

  • Light microscopy- glomeruli appear normal (hence called "minimal change")
  • Immunofluorescence studies- no Ig or complement deposits
  • Electron microscopy- diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells/podocytes

The image given below shows biopsy findings seen in minimal change disease on light microscopy.

 

The illustration given below shows the effacement of foot processes of podocytes as seen in MCD.

The majority of children will respond to corticosteroid (prednisone/prednisolone) treatment and will achieve complete remission (urine PCR<0.2 or <1+ protein on urine dipstick).

Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the hospital with high-grade fever and altered consciousness. On examination, the patient had neck rigidity and pain when bending the neck. A lumbar puncture was performed and it showed a WBC count of 1500 cells/μL, majority being neutrophils, elevated pressure with protein of 120 mg/dL, and a glucose level of 70 mg/dL (blood glucose level - 300 mg/dL). How will you manage the index case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with high fever, altered consciousness, neck rigidity, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing neutrophilic pleocytosis with low sugar point toward a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis. The initial treatment involves the administration of 3rd-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone along with vancomycin for 10–14 days. 

Hyperglycemia due to the pathological stress from the infection can mask the reduced CSF glucose. It can be correctly inferred from CSF/blood glucose ratio. A ratio <0.4 is highly significant for bacterial meningitis.

The most common cause of meningitis in adults over 20 years of age is Streptococcus pneumoniae. 

The classic clinical triad of meningitis includes fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity. Other common symptoms include decreased consciousness, nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and seizures. Cutaneous signs such as petechiae, purpura, or an erythematous macular rash may be present.

Kernig's sign and Brudzinski's sign can indicate meningeal irritation. Kernig's sign is positive when there is resistance and pain in extending the knee with the hip flexed at 90 degrees. Brudzinski's sign is positive when there is involuntary flexion of the hips and knees in response to passive neck flexion. However, these signs may not be reliable in certain patient groups, such as infants, elderly individuals, or those with altered mental status.

When bacterial meningitis is suspected, blood cultures should be obtained, and empirical antimicrobial therapy should be initiated without delay. The diagnosis is confirmed by examining cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). CSF analysis shows increased polymorphonuclear leukocytes, decreased glucose concentration, increased protein concentration, and increased opening pressure. CSF bacterial cultures and Gram stain are used to identify the causative organism.

Prompt initiation of empirical antimicrobial therapy is crucial in suspected cases of bacterial meningitis. Commonly used antibiotics include third- or fourth-generation cephalosporins (such as ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or cefepime) that cover Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae and Vancomycin if there is a high suspicion of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. Ampicillin with metronidazole is added when Listeria monocytogenes is suspected, particularly in neonates, pregnant women, individuals over 50 years, and immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: An epidemiologist wants to identify missing cases of HIV-positive individuals in the community, that were not on the notified cases list. This process is known as?
questions.solution:
Sentinel surveillance is a method of identifying the missing cases that are not on the notified cases list.

Sentinel surveillance helps in identifying the missing cases, in addition to the already existing new and old cases. It is used for supplementing routine notifications. The sentinel data collected in this type of surveillance can estimate the disease prevalence (old and new cases) in the total population. This system provides more valuable and detailed information compared to what is obtained from traditional notification systems.

Monitoring is the analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the health status or environment of a population.

Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and ill health.

Evaluation compares results with the intended objectives, or more simply assesses how well a program is performing.

Related Pearl: Sentinel Surveillance

  • Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in surveillance of diseases.
  • It detects the total case load and is used to identify the missing cases that are not notified among the old and new cases.
  • Sentinel data from the same is extrapolated to the entire population and the prevalence can be commented on.
  • Advantages: Bias in reporting is minimized and the feedback is simplified.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman who underwent massive ileal resection is started on total parenteral nutrition through central venous access. What is the least likely complication of this method of nutrition?
questions.solution:
Aspiration pneumonia is the least likely complication to occur in a patient receiving total parenterla nutrition.

Aspiration pneumonia is more common in enteral feeding and can be prevented by placing the patient in semi-recumbent position while feeding.

Complications of enteral nutrition:

1. Tube-related (most common)

  • Malposition
  • Displacement
  • Blockage
  • Breakage/leakage
  • Local complications (e.g. erosion of skin/mucosa)

2. Gastrointestinal

  • Diarrhoea
  • Bloating, nausea, vomiting
  • Abdominal cramps
  • Aspiration
  • Constipation

3. Metabolic/biochemical

  • Electrolyte disorders
  • Vitamin, mineral, trace element deficiencies
  • Drug interactions

4. Infective

  • Exogenous (handling contamination)
  • Endogenous (patient)

Related Pearl: Complications of total parenteral nutrition

A. Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypoglycemia/hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

C. Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

D. Related to IV line

  • On insertion: Pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydro mediastinum
  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

E. Related to motility

  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones

questions.text: Absence of the Nitabuch layer in the uterine decidua will lead to which of the following placental abnormalities?
questions.solution:
The absence of the Nitabuch layer in the uterine decidua leads to the placenta accreta spectrum.

The Nitabuch layer (also known as the fibrinoid layer) is a layer of fibrinoid degeneration where the invading trophoblasts meet the decidua basalis.


This Nitabuch layer is absent in the placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), which is characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta.

Risk factors for PAS include associated placenta previa and previous cesarean delivery.

Types of the morbidly adherent placenta:

  • Placenta accreta: Villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta: Villi invade the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta: Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

Other options: 

Option A: Placenta previa is a condition in which the placenta is implanted at the lower uterine segment. Patients present with painless, apparently causeless vaginal bleeding after the 28th week. Some of the risk factors include prior cesarean section, suction and curettage, advanced maternal age, and smoking.

Option B: Attachment of the umbilical cord to the membranes is known as velamentous insertion of placenta. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. If the leash of blood vessels traverses through the membranes overlying the internal os, in front of the presenting part, the condition is called vasa previa.

Option C: Placenta succenturiata is the presence of one or more unequally sized smaller placental lobes at distant sites from the bulk of the placenta. Vessels are present in the intervening membranes that connect the two lobes. It is associated with complications like vasa previa, postpartum uterine atony, postpartum hemorrhage, and endometritis.

questions.text: A multiparous woman presented with a bulge protruding from the vagina that increases in size on coughing and sneezing. Which of the following is not a complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of pelvic organ prolapse. Urge incontinence is not a complication of this condition. 

Pelvic organ prolapse is a condition where the pelvic organs herniate into the vagina due to weakness of the supports of the uterus. The patient may present with a feeling of a bulge protruding through the vaginal opening. Prolapse is aggravated by straining so the bulge increases on sneezing and coughing. It reduces on lying down, or by manual reduction. It may be accompanied by micturition disturbances like difficulty in initiating micturition or frequency of micturition. Rectal symptoms and coital difficulties can be present depending on the degree of prolapse.

Complications of prolapse:

  • Kinking of the ureter with resulting renal damage can occur in procidentia and enterocele.
  • Chronic Urinary tract infection due to retention of urine in a cystocele, and can lead to upper renal tract infec­tion and renal damage.
  • Decubitus ulcer due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes.
  • Stress incontinence occurs when the internal urinary meatus and neck of the bladder descend below the level of pelvic floor muscles.
  • Cancer of the vagina can rarely occur over the decubitus ulcer and if the ring pessary is left in over a long period.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

Age/condition Desire for pregnancy Desire for menstruation Surgery
<40 No Yes Fothergill's operation
>40 No No  Ward Mayo's vaginal hysterectomy
>60(medically unfit for hysterectomy)        -      - Le Forts repair
Prolapse during pregnancy /puerperium     -       - Ring Pessary

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

questions.text: A 45 year male patient came to OPD with varicose veins. He was sent for further investigation. During a duplex scan, saphenofemoral junction was identified using a Mickey Mouse sign. Which of the following structure is not a component of Mickey mouse sign in B mode duplex scan?
questions.solution:
The External iliac artery is not a component of the Mickey mouse sign in B mode duplex scan of the lower limb.

Mickey mouse sign is seen in the B mode duplex scan in the groin region.

Mickey mouse sign is due to the great saphenous vein, common femoral vein, common femoral artery, and saphenofemoral junction.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is a patient with fever unlikely to have clubbing?
questions.solution:
Rheumatic fever is associated with fever but not clubbing while all the other conditions listed are known to be associated with clubbing.

Clubbing is a clinical finding characterized by selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue, especially on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma, asbestosis
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Tuberculosis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Patent ductus arteriosus (causes differential clubbing)
    • Aortic aneurysm 
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
    • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • Neurological
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)
  • Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is an associated feature in clubbing seen due to primary or metastatic lung disease, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis. It can be diagnosed using a bone radiograph or MRI.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing:

Schamroth sign: This sign is elicited by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, whereas in clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window is obliterated. 

Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: This is defined by the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, the profile angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions
