questions.text: A child presented with complaints of itching and discharges on flexure aspect of elbow and the lesions were red as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of diffuse, erythematous, itchy plaques on the flexural aspects of the elbow of a child is suggestive of atopic dermatitis.

Atopic dermatitis is the cutaneous manifestation of atopy, characterized by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema.

There is a clear genetic predisposition. A characteristic defect is an impaired epidermal barrier. In many patients a mutation in the gene encoding filaggrin (a structural protein in the stratum granulosum) is responsible. 

Patients may display many immunoregulatory abnormalities, including increased IgE synthesis, increased serum IgE levels, and delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions.

The disease progresses in three phases: Infantile, childhood, and adult.

In infants, the lesions of atopic eczema most frequently start on the face but may occur anywhere on the skin surface. Often, the napkin area is relatively spared. When the child begins to crawl, the exposed surfaces, especially the extensor aspect of the knees and elbows are most involved. The lesions consist of erythema and discrete or confluent oedematous papules. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing. Secondary infection and lymphadenopathy are common.

From 18 to 24 months onwards (childhood phase), the sites most characteristically involved are the elbow and knee flexures, a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification may be seen depending on the skin type on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles. The sides of the neck may show reticulate pigmentation, sometimes referred to as an atopic dirty neck. The erythematous and oedematous papules tend to be replaced by lichenification.

The picture in adults is essentially similar to that in later childhood, with lichenification, especially of the flexures and hands.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy, who has been diagnosed with Tourette's disorder, keeps shouting and speaking obscene words and phrases abruptly in the classroom. What is this tic known as?
questions.solution:
The use of obscene words or phrases, seen in this child with Tourette's disorder, is known as Coprolalia.

Coprolalia is a complex vocal tic characterized by the involuntary and repetitive use of obscene or socially unacceptable words or phrases. Mental coprolalia, which is more common in Tourette's disorder than coprolalia, involves the sudden intrusion of obscene words into the patient's mind. Coprolalia can also be seen in some cases of schizophrenia.

Motor and vocal tics are divided into simple and complex types.

Simple motor tics Complex motor tics

Composed of repetitive, rapid contractions of functionally similar muscle groups.

 More purposeful and ritualistic than simple tics.

Examples:

Eye-blinking

Neck-jerking

Shoulder-shrugging

Facial-grimacing

Head shaking

 Examples: 

Grooming behaviors

Smelling of objects

Jumping

Touching behaviors

Echopraxia (imitation of observed behavior)

Copropraxia (display of obscene gestures)
Simple vocal tics Complex vocal tics
It consists of sounds that do not form words. Repeating words or phrases out of context.
Examples:

Coughing

Throat-clearing

Grunting

Sniffing

Snorting

Barking

 Examples: 

Coprolalia (use of obscene words or phrases)

Palilalia (a person's repeating his or her words)

Echolalia (repetition of the last-heard words of others)

Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations, called tics. The average age of onset of tics is between 4 years and 6 years of age, although the peak age for the severity of tics is between 10 and 12 years. The onset of tics is seen before the age of 18 years and the tics may wax and wane in frequency. Over half of the children diagnosed with Tourette's syndrome also meet the criteria for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD).

For a diagnosis of Tourette's disorder, based on the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5 (DSM-5) criteria, the presence of at least 2 motor tics along with at least 1 vocal tic persisting for a period greater than 12 months is required.

Behavioral interventions like habit reversal, comprehensive behavioral intervention, and exposure and response prevention are the first line of treatment. Pharmacotherapy must be included in severe cases when they cause social and emotional problems, depression, or isolation. First-line agents are antipsychotics like aripiprazole and risperidone or noradrenergic agents like atomoxetine, clonidine, and guanfacine which can be used as adjunctive for comorbid ADHD. Alternative treatments are tetrabenazine, topiramate, and tetrahydrocannabinol.

questions.text: During ward rounds, a resident doctor inserts an intravenous cannula in the patient's hand as shown in the image. What is the gauge size of this cannula?
questions.solution:
The image shows a pink intravenous cannula and the size is 20G. It has a flow rate of 67 mL/ min.

Other options:

Option B: The blue IV cannula is 22G with a flow rate of 42 mL/min.

Option C: The orange IV cannula is 14G with a flow rate of 270 mL/min.

Option D: The green IV cannula is 18G with a flow rate of 103 mL/min.

A standard wire gauge (SWG) is used to size cannulas. It is a measure of the cross-sectional area. Larger cannulae have a smaller gauge number.

Tip:

A simple mnemonic to remember these in descending order of their flow rates is nature. The mantle zone of the earth is orange, the land is grey, the grass is green, the butterfly on the grass is pink, the sky is blue, and the sun is yellow.

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae

questions.text: A lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and rashes on her face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical case describes a young lady with fever, oral ulcers, and photosensitivity. The image shows a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly-shaped rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds (malar rash). The clinical presentation along with the image showing malar rash point to a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

The clinical manifestations of SLE include  Acute, subacute cutaneous manifestations (photosensitivity, malar or maculopapular rash) and Chronic cutaneous manifestations (discoid lupus, panniculitis, lichen planus-like), Oral or nasal ulcers, non scarring aloplecia, Synovitis involving ≥2 joints, Serositis, hemolytic anemia, leukopenia(<4,000/mcL), thrombocytopenia(<1,00,000/mcL), Protein/Creatinine ratio >0.5, RBC casts. Immunological manifestations include Antinuclear antibodies, Anti ds DNA, Anti-smith antibody, Antiphospholipid antibody and low serum complement (C3,C4).

According to the Systemic Lupus International Collaborating Clinics (SLICC) criteria, at least 4 out of 11 of the above criteria must be positive with at least one clinical and one immunological criteria well documented to diagnose SLE. However, if a renal biopsy is suggestive of lupus nephritis and lupus autoantibodies are positive, other criteria are not required.

Life-threatening manifestations include - lupus nephritis leading to end-stage renal disease, myocarditis, venous and arterial thrombosis (including stroke and myocardial infarction), ARDS, and vasculitis involving the gastrointestinal vasculature - leading to ischemia, bleeding, and sepsis.

Other options : 

Option a : Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations like heliotope rash(nasolabial fold is involved), V-sign, Shawl sign, gottron's papules. The pattern of muscle involvement helps distinguish a myopathy from a cerebral, spinal cord, neuronal or neuromuscular junction cause. It is commonly associated with an underlying malignancy.

Option c : Rosacea is a chronic disorder with fluctuating severity. It is triggered by exposure to sunlight, spicy food, alcohol, or emotional disturbances. Patients also develop telangiectasia later. They also tend to develop rapid flushing due to temperature change. Rosacea is more common in women aged 30 to 50 years.

Option d : Melasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy and is most marked in brunettes. It occurs due to increased levels of estrogen and progesterone, stimulating the activity of melanocytes with melanocyte-stimulating hormone. It resolves on its own after pregnancy. Hypermelanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, the forehead, and the chin.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is undergoing management of a chronic ulcer with hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT). All of the following statements are correct about this treatment modality, except:

choices.text: It stimulates angiogenesis in chronic, non-healing wounds
It is associated with an increased ischemia–reperfusion injury
In diabetic ulcers, HBOT reduces the risk of proximal amputation
Middle ear barotrauma is a common adverse effect of HBOT chamber

questions.solution:
Hyperbaric oxygen therapy produces controlled oxidative stress which is associated with reduced occurrence of ischemia–reperfusion injury. Hence, option B is incorrect.

Chronic, non-healing wounds are usually associated with a decreased blood supply. Oxygen therapy in such cases results in improved angiogenesis (option A) and the production of reactive oxygen species prevents the growth of bacteria in the wounds. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) using pressurized oxygen is the most commonly used modality. 

HBOT chambers provide 100% oxygen at higher than atmospheric pressure. There is a significant increase in partial pressure of oxygen in the tissues which results in the production of a controlled oxidative stress. This produces improved leukocyte function, neovascularization in the wound bed, and increased local growth factors that improve wound healing. The controlled oxidative stress is associated with blunting of ischemia-reperfusion injury. 

HBOT chambers can be either single-person chambers or multiple-person chambers. The image below shows a single-person HBOT chamber:


HBOT is indicated for the management of the following wounds and ulcers:

  • Clostridial myonecrosis and necrotizing soft tissue infections
  • Diabetic ulcers
  • Radiation-induced tissue or bone necrosis
  • Refractory osteomyelitis
  • Thermal burns

In cases where it was employed for the management of diabetic foot ulcers, HBOT significantly improved wound healing and was associated with a reduced risk of proximal amputation (option C). 

Complications of HBOT are mostly related to the adverse effects of increased pressure inside HBOT chambers. The most common complications are middle ear barotrauma (option D) and sinus barotrauma. Other complications include dental barotrauma, pulmonary barotrauma, and seizures from CNS oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: A 45 year female came in with her investigations for a breast lump. Mammography showed 4 satellite nodules in the same breast. FNAC of the mass and the nodules turned out to be positive for malignancy. Which of the following is the best treatment modality in her case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of carcinoma of the breast with satellite nodules. This implies that the patient is suffering from T4b disease as per the TNM staging causing stage III B disease. 

The preferred treatment of choice in such patients is modified radical mastectomy combined with neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Pre-operative chemotherapy and postoperative radiotherapy will add to the benefit of the patients. 

Considerations for treatment of Stage III A and III B disease is summarized in the flowchart as shown below. 

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

Breast conservative surgery is also known as segmental mastectomy, lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, wide local excision, and tylectomy.

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Subcutaneous mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast without overlying skin.
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Axillary lymph nodes (Levels I + II ± III)
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iversion) mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular lymph nodes
  • Super radical mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular + Mediastinal lymph nodes

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presented with abdominal distension, reduced urine output, and pedal edema. His serum creatinine was 1.6 mg/dL. What is the next line of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given features of abdominal distension in a chronic alcoholic are suggestive of alcoholic liver disease while reduced urine output, pedal edema, and elevated serum creatinine are suggestive of renal failure.

The presence of renal failure in the presence of alcoholic liver disease points towards the diagnosis of hepatorenal syndrome. Among the given options, octreotide plus albumin will be the next line of management.                   

Octreotide is a long-acting somatostatin analogue that causes splanchnic vasoconstriction and improves renal perfusion pressure.

Intravenous albumin is a volume expander and is associated with an increase in blood pressure due to albumin’s ability to sequester vasodilators. Albumin is used in combination with other vasoconstrictor agents such as terlipressin or octreotide. 

Hepatorenal syndrome is a form of acute renal failure without renal pathology that occurs in some patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure. There is an increased splanchnic production of vasodilators (nitric oxide) in patients with cirrhosis and portal hypertension which leads to systemic arterial underfilling resulting in the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). RAAS activation causes renal vasoconstriction which leads to decreased renal perfusion resulting in hepatorenal syndrome. 

Treatment: 

  • Definitive therapy: Liver transplantation 
  • Pharmacological management: (Based on the order of availability)

Drugs which cause splanchnic vasoconstriction:

  1. Terlipressin 
  2. Noradrenaline 
  3. Midodrine 
  4. Octreotide 

Vasoconstrictors are given with intravenous albumin (20-40 mg/day). Intravenous albumin must be stopped when its serum levels are more than 4 g/dl as large amounts of albumin can cause volume overload, pulmonary edema, and the need for dialysis in Type 1 HRS.

Other treatment options include dialysis and transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt.


Other options:

Options A and B: Steroids and heparin have no role in the management of hepatorenal syndrome.

Option C: Torsemide is a diuretic and diuretics should be stopped in Hepatorenal syndrome as they can cause intravascular volume depletion worsening the condition.

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: What is the age group distribution for vulval cancer?
questions.solution:
The age group distribution for vulval cancer is 55 to 85 years (Option C).

Vulval cancer is a malignancy of elderly women, usually in their 6th and 7th decades of life. It can also be seen in younger women who have been diagnosed with sexually transmitted infections such as HIV and HPV infections.The average age of diagnosis is at 65 years.

Persistent HPV,HSV infections, smoking,chronic immunosuppression and chronic inflammation such as lichen sclerosis are risk factors.Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) are the preinvasive condition of the vulva.

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vulvar cancer. The most common site of vulvar cancer is labia majora > Clitoris > Labia Minora.

Vulval cancer generally presents with vulvar pruritus, vulvar swelling, lump or an ulcer. Pain is usually a late feature of the disease. 

The lump is seen as a pigmented papular raised area and the ulcers often have everted margins and usually bleed and cause an offensive vulval discharge.

The most common type of spread in vulval cancer is lymphatic route.The first lymph node to be involved is the superficial inguinal lymph node and hence, the sentinel lymph node biopsy is helpful for evaluating the spread of vulval cancer and helps attain an adequate surgical procedure with a good prognosis. 

Treatment of the vulval cancer generally involves simple or radical, partial or total vulvectomy for the management of primary tumor and inguinofemoral lymph node dissection for involvement of the lymph nodes. This is decided based on the staging of the disease. 

 

Related Pearl: Staging of Vulval Cancer (FIGO)

Stage Features
I Tumor confined to vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm , confined to the vulva or perineum, with negative nodes
II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with negative nodes
III Tumor of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IIIA i) With 1 lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm) or,
  ii)1-2 lymph node micrometastases(<5mm)
IIIB i) With 2 or more lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm), or
  ii) 3 or more lymph node micrometastases (<5 mm)
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread
IV Tumor invades other regional structures (upper 2/3rd urethra, upper 2/3rd vagina) or distant structures
IVA Tumour invades any of the following:
  i) Upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  ii) Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IVB Any distant metastasis including pelvic lymph nodes

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

questions.text: A patient underwent the following procedure for the management of portal hypertension. Which of the following is an early complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
The image shows the transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) procedure with the viatorr device. An early complication of the TIPS procedure is metabolic encephalopathy.

The main indication of TIPS is variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment and intractable ascites.

The shunts are inserted under local anesthesia, analgesia, and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. A guidewire is inserted via the internal jugular vein and superior vena cava into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

The major complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion.

Portal hypertension is defined by a portal pressure >5 mmHg.

Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is a treatment option whereby a percutaneous connection is created within the liver, between the portal and systemic circulations, to reduce portal pressure in patients with complications related to portal hypertension.

Complications of TIPS procedure:

  • Intraoperative complications- capsular hemorrhage
  • Early complication- hepatic encephalopathy
  • Late complication- recurrent variceal bleed
  • Delayed complication- total shunt occlusion

Shunts for portal hypertension:

  • Non-selective shunt- bowel and splenic blood is shunted
    • Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)
    • ECK fistula (portocaval shunt)
    • Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)
  • Selective shunt- only splenic blood is shunted
    • Warren shunt (distal lienorenal shunt)
    • Inokuchi shunt 

Related Pearl: Classification of Portal Hypertension

  • Prehepatic
    • Portal vein thrombosis
    • Splenic vein thrombosis
    • Massive splenomegaly (Banti's syndrome)
  • Hepatic
    • Presinusoidal
      • Schistosomiasis
      • Congenital hepatic fibrosis
    • Sinusoidal
      • Cirrhosis of Liver (Most Common)
      • Alcoholic hepatitis
    • Postsinusoidal
      • Hepatic sinusoidal obstruction (venoocclusive syndrome)
  • Posthepatic
    • Budd-Chiari syndrome
    • Inferior vena caval webs
    • Cardiac causes
      • Restrictive cardiomyopathy
      • Constrictive pericarditis
      • Severe congestive heart failure

questions.text: You are assisting your first case of open abdominal surgery. The senior professor asked you to make the incision first. The nurse hands over a fresh set of sterilized instruments with various Bard-Parker blades. Which blade would you choose generally for making an abdominal incision?
questions.solution:
The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions. Essentially a larger version of the number 10, it has a flat, unsharpened back edge and a short, curved cutting edge. These blades are best for creating large incisions, often through thick skin.

Other options-

Option (A): 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy. This is also known as a stab knife. 

Option (C): 15-blade for minor surgical procedures 

Uses of 15-scalpel blade:

  • To make precise skin incisions in dermatosurgery
  • Minor surgical procedures
  • Select ocular procedures (15C blade)
  • Select plastic surgery procedures (15C blade)

Option (D): 12-blade is a small, pointed, crescent-shaped blade used typically as a suture cutter. It is most sharp on the inside edge of its curve.

questions.text: A woman develops puerperal sepsis following a cesarean section. Which of the following antibiotics are indicated in empirical therapy?
questions.solution:
Polymicrobial antibiotic coverage is indicated in cases of puerperal sepsis from postpartum endometritis as they are mostly polymicrobial with a mixture of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. Gentamicin and clindamycin are given empirically to patients with uncomplicated infections of the genital tract. Ampicillin is added if the patient has signs of sepsis or if enterococcal infection is suspected. Metronidazole is not indicated as an empirical therapy.

Infection of the genial tract has also been termed puerperal sepsis and includes endometritis, endo-myometritis, and endo-parametritis, and a combination of all is called pelvic cellulitis. However, routine use of antibiotic prophylaxis has now reduced the incidence of puerperal fever following cesarean delivery.

Other causes of puerperal fever include:

  • Urinary tract infection
  • Breast infection (abscess/mastitis)
  • Pelvic infection including septic pelvic thrombophlebitis
  • Respiratory infections

questions.text: The absence of the SRY gene results in which of the following?

choices.text: Development of ovaries and Mullerian system

questions.solution:
The absence of the SRY gene results in the development of the ovaries and the Mullerian system.

In this situation, the gonads will develop into ovaries and the Mullerian duct will differentiate into the uterus, fallopian tubes, and the upper part of the vagina. The master gene responsible for this is the WNT4 gene.

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, which has a sex-determining region called the SRY gene.

If the Y chromosome is present, the protein called testis determining factor produced by the SRY gene will lead to the development of testis as the gonads. The Sertoli cells of the testis will then produce Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS; also known as Anti-Müllerian hormone, AMH) that will cause the Müllerian ducts to regress.

Functions of SRY and WNT4:

SRY gene WNT4 gene

Development of the medullary/testes cords

The disappearance of medullary/testes cords

Formation of the tunica albuginea

Failure of formation of tunica albuginea

Failure of development of cortical/ovarian cords 

 Development of ovaries with typical cortical cords

Related Pearl: Sexual Differentiation

questions.text: A 15-month-old child who is posted for a minor surgical procedure is brought by his mother for preoperative evaluation. What would be the recommended period of fasting for this child?

choices.text: 6 hours for light meal, 2 hours for clear fluids
6 hours for fried foods, 2 hours for clear fluids
6  hours for light meal, 4 hours for clear fluids
6 hours for fried foods, 4 hours for clear fluids

questions.solution:
The recommended preoperative fasting period for this child is 6 hours for a light meal and 2 hours for clear fluids.

Recommended preoperative fasting periods for all above 1 year of age are 2 hours for clear fluids, 6 hours for a light meal, and 8 hours for fried, fatty food.

Recommended preoperative fasting periods for neonates and infants are 6 hours for solids/ formula feeds/ cow's milk, and 4 hours for breast milk.

The goal of recommending preoperative fasting periods is to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient who is known to have chronic kidney disease is planned for dialysis treatment. Which of the following is not an indication for dialysis ?
questions.solution:
Severe coagulopathy is a relative contraindication for dialysis. 

Dialysis is a form of renal replacement therapy. Here the kidney's function of blood filtration is supplemented with artificial equipment to remove excess water, solutes, and toxins.

Dialysis broadly has 3 types that include hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis and continuous renal replacement therapy.

Indications for dialysis include: 

  • Refractory metabolic acidosis that has failed to respond to medical treatment
  • Refractory hyperkalemia 
  • Extracellular volume expansion despite diuretic therapy
  • Uremic symptoms
  • eGFR <10 mL/min per 1.73 m2 
  • Any toxic ingestions

Note: Non-refractory hyperkalemia can be managed by: Restricting the dietary potassium intake, insulin, calcium gluconate or calcium chloride, inhalational β-agonist therapy and potassium binding ion-exchange resin.

Contraindications for dialysis include inability to secure vascular access, difficult vascular access, needle phobia, cardiac failure and coagulopathy.

 

Related Pearl: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

Difference between Hemodialysis and Peritoneal dialysis

Hemodialysis Peritoneal dialysis
Comparatively difficult access Easy access
Better clearance Good clearance
Short time for treatment Longer time may be required
Based on :

Solute removal through a semi-permeable membrane.

Based on principle :

Solute removal through a peritoneal membrane
Have to leave home Can be done at home
Complications:
  • Hypotension
  • Disequilibrium syndrome
  • Muscle cramps
  • Anaphylaxis reaction

Complications :

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances
  • Residual uremia

questions.text: Isolation in a separate room is mandatory for which of the following air-borne infections?
questions.solution:
Among the given options isolation in a separate room is mandatory for measles.

Isolation is defined as the separation of an infected person or animal for the period of communicability in places to prevent direct or indirect transmission to susceptible individuals. 

Measles is an infectious disease mainly seen in the childhood age group. It is caused by an RNA paramyxovirus and is transmitted to humans primarily by droplet infection and also through airborne transmission. The period of isolation is from the onset of symptoms (catarrhal stage) to the fourth day of the rash.

Features include

  • The prodromal phase-characterized by fever, cough, conjunctivitis, coryza, 
  • The eruptive phase- macular or maculopapular rash begins behind the ears and spreads to the face, neck, and extremities. Koplik's spots are rashes seen in the buccal mucosa opposite the first and second molar. 

Some of the complications of measles include otitis media, laryngotracheobronchitis (croup), post-infectious measles, or subacute sclerosing pan encephalitis (SSPE). SSPE is a rare but fatal complication. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at supportive care such as relieving the symptoms, treating dehydration, and isolating patients.

The below images show a characteristic rash in measles and Koplik's spots on the buccal mucosa. 

Other options:

Option B: Rabies is transmitted via a bite or scratch from an infected animal. Contraction of rabies by inhalation of virus-containing aerosols is extremely rare. Human-to-human transmission is possible but has not been confirmed.

Option C: Nipah is transmitted mainly from direct contact with sick pigs or their contaminated tissues. To prevent human-to-human transmission, close unprotected contact with infected people is avoided. Regular hand hygiene should be followed when caring for or visiting infected people.

Option D: If the diagnosis is confirmed as aseptic meningitis, the patient can often be discharged home. Isolation is required if the meningitis is of infectious etiology.

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

Disease

 

Duration of Isolation

Chickenpox

 

Until all lesions are crusted – 6 days usually.

Measles

 

From onset of catarrhal stage to 7 days of rash.

Cholera, diphtheria

 

3 days after tetracycline start until 48 hours.

Shigellosis and salmonellosis

 

Until 3 consecutive negative stool cultures.

Hepatitis A

 

3 weeks.

Influenza

 

3 days after onset.

Polio

 

2 weeks in adult; 6 weeks in children.

Tuberculosis (sputum +)

 

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy.

Herpes zoster

 

6 days after onset of rash.

Mumps

 

Until swelling subsides.

Pertussis

 

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease.

Meningococcal meningitis

 

Until first 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed

Streptococcal pharyngitis

 

Until first 6 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed

questions.text: Hematemesis and melena are the usual presenting features of bleeding located _________
questions.solution:
Hematemesis and melena are the usual presenting features of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Upper GI bleeding is derived from a source proximal to the ligament of Treitz.

The ligament of Treitz is part of the duodenojejunal junction and forms the line of demarcation for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the ER after being in a road traffic accident. His BP is 90/60mm Hg and physical examination reveals dullness to percussion over the left chest. USG reveals hemothorax. Which of the following is not an indication for surgical thoracotomy in this patient?

choices.text: >1500 ml drainage after placing an intercostal tube
Continuous bleeding through intercostal tube of 50 ml/hour for 2 hours

questions.solution:
Ongoing Tube Thoracostomy drainage of >200 ml/hr (NOT 50 ml/hr) for 3 consecutive hours or more (NOT 2 hrs) in non-coagulopathic patients with hemothorax is an indication for surgical thoracotomy.

Chest Injuries:

Hemothorax and pneumothorax are the most common injuries from both blunt and penetrating thoracic trauma.

Indications for surgical thoracotomy:

  • Initial Tube Thoracostomy drainage of >1000 ml (penetrating injury) or >1500 ml (blunt injury) of frank blood
  • Ongoing Tube Thoracostomy drainage of >200 ml/ hr for 3 consecutive hours in non-coagulopathic patients with hemothorax
  • Caked hemothorax despite the placement of two chest tubes.
  • Tracheobronchial injury
  • Selected descending torn aorta or great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac Herniation
  • Massive air leak from chest tube with inadequate ventilation
  • Open Pneumothorax
  • Esophageal Perforation
  • Air embolism

questions.text: An observer notes that the maternal deaths that happened in hospital deliveries in the past year are higher than maternal deaths in home deliveries. He concludes that homes are a safer place for delivery than hospitals. This is an example of :
questions.solution:
The given association is an association that appears due to improper comparison. It may lead to a spurious association or an association when none actually existed.

Here, maternal mortality is likely to have been higher in-hospital deliveries compared to home deliveries because hospitals attract women at high risk for delivery because of their special equipment and expertise, whereas this is not necessarily the case with home deliveries. When confounding factors and selection biases are not accounted for, it may result in incorrect conclusions regarding the association. So the conclusion that homes are a safer place for delivery than hospitals is likely to have been spurious or artifactual.

The association can be broadly grouped under three headings:

  • Spurious association
  • Indirect association
  • Direct (causal) association
    • One-to-one causal association
    • Multifactorial causation

Other options:

Option A: Direct (causal) association- Two variables are stated to be causally related (AB) if a change in A is followed by a change in B. When factor A is present, disease B must result. Measles is one such disease in which such a relation exists.

Option B: Indirect association- The indirect association is an association between a variable and disease due to the presence of another factor, known or unknown, that is also known as the "confounding" variable. 

Option D: Multifactorial causation is seen in non-communicable diseases or conditions (e.g., Coronary heart disease) where the etiology is multifactorial.

questions.text: Cortical nephrocalcinosis is not seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Hyperoxaluria causes medullary nephrocalcinosis. 

Causes of cortical nephrocalcinosis include:

  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
  • Graft rejection
  • Acute cortical necrosis
  • Chronic glomerulonephritis
  • Alport syndrome

Other causes of medullary nephrocalcinosis include:

  • Renal tubular acidosis - type 1
  • Medullary sponge kidney
  • Sarcoidosis and other causes of hypercalcemia
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypothyroidism

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a solitary thyroid nodule. Thyroid function tests demonstrate an elevated T4 and normal TSH. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the next best step in evaluating this patient.

A normal TSH level in this patient indicates that he/she is euthyroid. A solitary nodule in a euthyroid state needs further evaluation by USG.

USG is a non-invasive and inexpensive way to stratify the risk of the nodule into benign or malignant tissue.

Ultrasound findings within a nodule that are considered suspicious for malignancy include:

  • microcalcifications
  • hypervascularity
  • infiltrative margins
  • being hypoechoic compared with surrounding parenchyma

Benign nodules are easily compressible whereas malignant nodules tend to be hard and firm. Hence, benign nodules are easily deformed on applying pressure while performing USG. The malignant nodules do not deform as easily.

Other Options: 

Option A- FNAC is now only indicated after sonography and evidence of malignant nodules.

Option C- Thyroid autoantibodies are tested to rule out autoimmune thyroiditis in case the thyroid function tests come out abnormal. 

Option D- Radioactive iodine uptake test (RAIU) is only indicated in cases of toxic adenoma, ie, nodularity with features of thyroid toxicity

questions.text: A girl wakes the entire hostel dormitory screaming about a snake in the bathroom. The matron rushes in and sees her pointing at a rope. Which of the following best describes this?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, a rope being mistaken for a snake is an illusion. Illusions are perceptions that occur when a sensory stimulus is present but is incorrectly perceived and misinterpreted. 

Delusion Hallucination Illusion
A fixed false belief that is firmly held despite obvious contradictory evidence and that is not consistent with the person's social, educational, and cultural background. Perception in the absence of any external sensory stimulus Incorrect perception or misinterpretation of a sensory stimulus.
Eg: A belief that the person is a snake god. Eg: There is nothing in front of you but you can see a snake. Eg: There is a rope in front of you but you see it as a snake.

questions.text: You would perform a Pinard's maneuver for _____.

choices.text: Delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech delivery
Delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery

questions.solution:
Pinard's maneuver is done for frank breech extraction. The middle and the index fingers are placed in the popliteal fossa to abduct and flex the fetal leg. The fetal ankle is then grasped and breech extraction is accomplished as shown below.

Mc Robert's maneuver, Gaskin's maneuver, and Rubin's maneuver are all used in the management of shoulder dystocia. 

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or rarely the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively, following the delivery of the head. A positive turtle sign may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum. The incidence of shoulder dystocia increases with increasing birth weight, which can be due to maternal obesity, gestational diabetes, post-term pregnancy, and multiparity. Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia:

  • Gentle downward traction of the fetal head with suprapubic pressure 
  • McRoberts maneuver: Flexing the legs on the abdomen with concurrent suprapubic pressure. This causes straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebrae, rotation of the symphysis pubis toward the maternal head, and a decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination. This tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

Woods corkscrew maneuver: Pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a cork­ screw fashion releases the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

  • Rubin's maneuver: The fetal shoulders are rocked from side to side by applying force to the maternal abdomen. If this is not successful, the pelvic hand pushes the most easily accessible fetal shoulder toward the anterior surface of the chest, producing a smaller bisacromial diameter. This permits displacement of the anterior shoulder from behind the symphysis.
  • Gaskin maneuver: (All fours maneuver): The parturient rolls onto her knees and hands and downward traction against the head and neck is applied, with the attempt to free the posterior shoulder.
  • Zavanelli maneuver: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery.
  • Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis.
  • Cleidotomy: Fracture of the clavicle using an instrument to free the anterior shoulder. Usually done for a dead fetus (shown below).

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Loveset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A woman who had undergone cholecystectomy presented three days after the surgery with abdominal pain and tachycardia. WBC count is 11000 cells/mm3. USG showed fluid collection 5x5 cm in right sub-hepatic space. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario involves a patient presenting with abdominal pain and tachycardia in the post-operative period  following cholecystectomy. An ultrasound scan (USG) reveals a fluid collection in the right sub-hepatic space, strongly suggesting a bile duct injury following cholecystectomy. As the patient presents more than 48 hours after the surgery, the next best step in managament would be to drain the fluid collection using a USG-guided pigtail catheter.

More than 80% of bile duct injuries occur during cholecystectomy. A bile duct injury can result in either bile leakage or stricture. Patients with bile leakage may present with fever, increasing abdominal pain, jaundice or bile leakage from an incision.

Management strategy:

  • Imaging: Ultrasonography to assess for a fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree 
  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
    • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
    • Parenteral antibiotics
  • Clear and thorough delineation of entire biliary anatomy
    • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if cystic-duct stump leak is suspected. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic.
    • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
    • HIDA scanning is also helpful to identify and quantitate bile leaks.
  • Definitive surgical correction
    1. Roux-en-Y choledochojejunostomy can be done for benign strictures or duct transections.
    2. Balloon dilatation with placement of a stent can be done for strictures of recent onset.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents with abrupt onset of fever, oliguria, nausea, smoky urine, and puffy eyes. The parents say that she had lesions on her face similar to the ones shown in the image below, 2 weeks ago which are now resolving. Which of the following findings will be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features with h/o honey-crusted lesions on the face (impetigo) are suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Patients will present with haematuria and urine microscopy will reveal red blood cells.

The PSGN patient presents with hematuria, red cell casts in the urine, azotemia, oliguria, hypertension, mild to moderate proteinuria, and edema (features of the nephritic syndrome). It usually appears 1 to 4 weeks after a streptococcal infection of the pharynx or skin (impetigo). It occurs most frequently in children 6 to 10 years of age. In adults, it is less benign. Poststreptococcal GN is caused by immune complexes containing streptococcal antigens and specific antibodies, which are formed in situ.

The histologic picture shows enlarged hypercellular glomeruli. The hypercellularity is caused by infiltration by leukocytes and proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells. The proliferation and leukocyte infiltration are typically global and diffuse.

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas- Infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. 

The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

questions.text: Which of the following would you expect in a patient with obstructive sleep apnea?
questions.solution:
A patient with obstructive sleep apnea will exhibit daytime sleepiness.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is diagnosed if the patient has either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances or daytime sleepiness, and ≥ 5 episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep. Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) occurs due to increased work of breathing, respiratory muscle impairment related to the increased load, and depressed central ventilatory response to hypoxemia and hypercapnia. The diagnosis of OHS requires: BMI ≥30 kg/m2 and PaCO2 ≥45 mmHg which signifies daytime alveolar hypoventilation.

This is known as the apnea-hypopnea index, and is calculated as: number of episodes ÷ number of hours of sleep. Each such episode should last for at least 10 seconds, resulting in ≥ 3% drop in oxygen saturation or a brain cortical arousal. OSA is diagnosed by overnight polysomnogram (PSG). This includes measurement of breathing, oxygenation, body position, cardiac rhythm, sleep stages, and snoring intensity. Note that waking hypoxemia or hypercarbia in a patient with OSA suggests cardiopulmonary disease or obesity hypoventilation syndrome.

Narcolepsy (options B, C and D) also presents with difficulty sustaining wakefulness and disturbed nocturnal sleep. However, unlike sleep apnea, patients with narcolepsy usually feel well-rested on awakening and then feel tired throughout the day. One of the most characteristic clinical features which is seen is cataplexy – sudden muscle weakness without a loss of consciousness, which is usually triggered by strong emotions, and hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations (hallucinations on going to sleep and on waking, respectively)

questions.text: The quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is:
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, the quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is 0/100 mL.

Drinking water should not contain any pathogenic organisms or bacteria indicative of faecal contamination. The primary bacterial indicator used to assess this is the coliform group of organisms. This is because they are present abundantly in the human intestine and can be easily detected by culture methods. 

The presumptive coliform test can be done by the multiple tube method or membrane filtration techniques. In the multiple-tube method, the water to be tested is inoculated into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium. These tubes are then incubated for 48 hours and examined. The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to other organisms. The presumption that the reaction is due to coliform organisms has to be confirmed. McConkey's lactose bile salt broth with bromocresol purple 25 as an indicator is used as the media. Escherichia coli or thermotolerant coliform bacteria should not be detected in any 100 ml sample. 

In samples of chlorinated water, confirmation of the presumptive test is necessary. This is done by subculturing the positive tubes in two tubes of brilliant green bile broth. It is based on the fact that E.Coli is the only coliform that can produce gas from lactose at 44°C.

Supplementary indicator organisms include fecal streptococci and sulfite-reducing clostridia. 

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters

 

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, there should be no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU for household drinking water.  Expressed in nephelometric turbidity units (NTU). It describes the cloudiness of water. >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye. <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, there should be no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU. Expressed in true color units (TCU). >15 TCU is detectable by naked eye. 
Taste and odor No health based guideline value has been proposed. It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. The cause must be investigated.
Temperature No health based guideline value has been proposed. Cool water is generally more palatable. High water temperature may enhance the growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters

  Guideline values Comments
Ammonia No health based guideline value has been proposed as it occurs in drinking water at concentrations well below those of health concern. Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium 0.9 mg/l There is very less evidence that aluminium in drinking water causes toxic effects.
Arsenic 0.01 mg/l Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride 250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears. Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/litre. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper 2 mg/l Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects and other adverse effects in people without normal copper homeostasis.
Fluoride 1.5 mg/l Above this guideline value, there is risk of dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis. Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre. A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent against methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects in susceptible populations  This guideline
value is based on the absence of adverse health effects (methaemoglobinaemia
and thyroid effects) at concentrations below 50 mg/L in epidemiological studies.
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent against methemoglobinemia in infants and the general population. Bottle-fed infant are at higher risk.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5. ______
Lead 0.01 mg/l The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury 0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury Nephrotoxicity is the main effect of mercury toxicity.
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Benzo(a)pyrene at 0.0007 mg/l They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic.
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give unacceptable taste. _________
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable. TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • They include a range of aerobic and facultative anaerobic, Gram-negative, non-spore-forming bacilli capable of fermenting lactose to acid or aldehyde at 35 to 37 degree Celsius within 24 hours. They include fecal and environmental organisms from wide genera.
    • E. coli and thermotolerant coliforms are a subset of the total coliform groups and they ferment lactose at 44 – 45 degrees Celsius and have the ability to produce indole.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci:
      • They are used as an indicator of fecal pollution.
      • Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens:
      • They are spore-forming organisms which are resistant to many disinfection methods.
      • They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination.
      • Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process and of the presence of other contaminants in the water.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts are indicators of disinfection and distribution of water. It measures a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidences of fecal contamination of water.

 

IV) Radiological aspects

  • Becquerel (Bq) is the unit used for radioactivity.
  • In the case of drinking water, the concentration of radioactivity is referred to as Bq/litre.
  • Proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He had a fever for the past two days and is a known case of severe COPD. His ECG is given below. What is the mechanism behind this condition?

choices.text: Automaticity of multiple foci in the atrium
Macro re-entry circuit in the right atrium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pulmonary disease and the ECG showing different p wave morphologies are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT). The mechanism triggering multifocal atrial tachycardia is the automaticity of multiple atrial foci.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals, hence it can be atrial fibrillation or multifocal atrial tachycardia. The next step is to look at the p waves. Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image). Whereas, in atrial fibrillation, there would be no distinct p waves seen.

 

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) occurs due to impulses arising from multiple abnormal foci in the atria. This leads to supraventricular tachycardia with p waves and QRS complexes of different morphologies. It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness.  

Identifying features in ECG:

  • Heart rate > 100, typically between 100 and 150 beats/min
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Narrow QRS complex
  • Discrete P waves with more than 3 different morphologies 
  • Variable PR interval

Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities. The calcium channel blockers verapamil or diltiazem are useful in slowing the atrial and ventricular rates. Radiofrequency ablation of the AV node is another treatment modality. Cardioversion is ineffective. 

Other options:

Option A - Increased atrial automaticity is seen in atrial tachycardia which is a narrow-complex tachycardia where abnormal P-wave morphology is observed. It can lead to an AV block if the rate is too rapid.

Option C - Atrial flutter is characterized by a macro re-entry circuit in the right atrium which is usually encircling the tricuspid annulus. ECG shows characteristic saw-tooth flutter waves.

Option D - Abnormal bands of conductive tissue between the atria and ventricles are seen in atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia. ECG shows a characteristic delta wave in the presence of these accessory pathways.

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the CT scan ?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. The image shown is a coronal section of paranasal sinuses at the level of anterior ethmoidal cells.

The cribriform plate is identified as a bony structure that separates the nasal cavity from the anterior cranial fossa. It is part of the ethmoid bone and is a sieve-like structure as it is pierced by the olfactory nerve fibers.

Crista Galli is also a part of ethmoid bone that projects superiorly from the cribriform plate. It provides attachment for the falx cerebri.

The anterior ethmoidal canal is identified by its location below the roof of ethmoidal air cells. The anterior ethmoidal artery passes through this canal and it is important to identify this to avoid bleeding from this vessel during sinus surgeries.

The posterior ethmoid canal/foramen is an opening in the ethmoid bone through which the posterior ethmoidal artery, vein, and nerve traverse. It is not visualized in this image as it is a coronal section at the level of anterior ethmoidal cells.

The optic nerve can be identified as an oval intraorbital structure in the coronal sections.

questions.text: All of the following favor a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Painless diarrhea or constipation does not favor the diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterized by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. 

The ROME IV criteria are used to diagnose irritable bowel syndrome, which requires at least 3 days a month in the last 3 months associated with 2 or more of the following:

  • improvement in abdominal pain or discomfort with defecation
  • onset associated with a change in frequency of stool
  • and/or an onset accompanied by a change in form or appearance of stool

The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with the following skin lesions on both the legs as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 4-year-old child with the lesions shown in the given image in a string of pearls or cluster of jewels sign is characteristic of linear IgA disease. The main target antigens seen in this disease are BP180 and BPAg2.

Linear IgA disease/chronic bullous disorder of childhood (CBDC) is an immunobullous disease of childhood that clinically can present as an annular arrangement of vesicles. It arises more abruptly in children compared to adults. It has a bimodal onset, below the age of 5 years and between the age of 60 - 65 years.

Clinical features include:

  • Mucous membrane lesions like oral erosions and ulcers are commonly seen. Nasal crusting and genital lesions may also occur.
  • Tense blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema are the characteristic triad of clinical features.
  • The blisters are arranged in a circular fashion, resembling a crown/cluster of jewels or a string of pearls appearance.
  • In young children, the distribution of lesions is perioral, perianal, and perineum.
  • In adults, the distribution is over the extensors and the trunk.

Note: The string of pearls or cluster of jewels sign, is characteristic of linear IgA disease but not pathognomic to this disease. 

The image below shows a string of pearls appearance in the Linear IgA disease.

Precipitating factors include:

  • Infections
  • Trauma
  • Vaccination
  • UV radiation exposure
  • Drugs like:
    • Vancomycin
    • Penicillin
    • NSAIDs

The main target antigens in this disease are BP180 and BPAg2 much more than BP230 or BPAg1.The mechanism of blister formation is due to the subepidermal splitting and neutrophilic infiltrate in the papillary dermis forming microabscesses. 

The image given below shows subepidermal blister formation and neutrophils infiltrate in the papillary dermis.

The diagnostic hallmark is the linear deposition of IgA deposits at DEJ identified by direct immunofluorescence.

Management involves:

  • First line:
    • Dapsone
    • Topical steroids with or without prednisolone
  • Second line:
    • Sulfa drugs like Sulfapyridine/ sulphamethoxypyridazine being alternatives for dapsone.
    • Anti‐inflammatory antibiotics like oxytetracycline, doxycycline with or without nicotinamide
  • Third line:
    • Mycophenolate
    • IVIG
    • Immunoadsorption

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification of the pelvis, convergent sidewalls are associated with:
questions.solution:
According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification of the pelvis, convergent sidewalls are associated with the android pelvis.

The female pelvis can be divided into 4 types based on the pelvic inlet's shape as follows:

  • Gynecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

The image and features of the different types of the female pelvis are given below

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis of the computed tomography (CT) image provided below?
questions.solution:
The given image is a CT pulmonary angiography showing a pulmonary (saddle) embolism.

CT pulmonary angiography using multi-detector CT is the best investigation for pulmonary embolism. 

An embolus in the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery is referred to as a saddle embolus. Pulmonary emboli (PE) originate from deep venous thromboses. Fragmented thrombi from DVTs are carried through progressively larger veins and the right side of the heart, before slamming into the pulmonary arterial vasculature.

Depending on the size of the embolus, it can occlude the main pulmonary artery; straddle the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolus); or pass out into the smaller, branching arteries.

The below image shows a CT thorax of saddle embolism.

Other options

Option A- Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is defined as an increase in vascular resistance of the pulmonary circulation involving a combination of vasoconstriction and remodeling of small vessels. Hemodynamically, it is defined as a systolic pulmonary artery pressure of more than 35 mmHg or a mean pulmonary artery pressure of more than 25 mmHg at rest.

A diameter of the main pulmonary artery at the level of its bifurcation of more than 29 mm helps in the diagnosis of PH.

Option B- Thoracic aortic aneurysm occurs due to the intrinsic weakness of the aortic wall and they rarely manifest with symptoms. A CECT scan is the most widely used for diagnosis and it assesses the size, extent, and location of the aneurysm.

The below image shows a CT scan of a ruptured thoracic aortic aneurysm. The black arrow is the aorta and the white arrow is blood in the thorax.

Option D- The mural thrombus of the aorta is the thrombus attached to the wall of an aorta. They occur in the normal or minimally atherosclerotic vessel. The modality for diagnosis of mural thrombi is CT or MRI angiography.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s and Modified Well’s criteria and PERC

 

Variable Points
Clinical symptoms and signs of DVT (leg swelling and pain with palpation of deep veins) 3.0
Alternative diagnosis less likely than PE 3.0
Heart rate > 100 beats/min 1.5
Immobilization for more than 3 days or surgery in the previous 4 weeks 1.5
Previous PE or DVT 1.5
Hemoptysis 1.0
Cancer (with treatment within past 6 months or palliative care) 1.0
Wells criteria Score
High > 6.0
Moderate 2.0 to 6.0
Low < 2.0
Modified Wells criteria Score
PE likely > 4.0
PE unlikely < or = 4.0

In cases where, modified Well's criteria <4, in order to rule out pulmonary embolism the following criteria must be met.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

  • Age < 50 years
  • Heart rate < 100 bpm
  • Oxyhemoglobin saturation on room air ≥ 95%
  • No prior history of venous thromboembolism
  • No recent (within 4 weeks) trauma or surgery requiring hospitalization
  • No presenting hemoptysis
  • No estrogen therapy
  • No unilateral leg swelling

questions.text: A 48-year-old working in the ship repair industry presents with a gradually progressive cough and difficulty breathing. Chest X-ray shows multiple linear opacities in both lower lungs. Investigations reveal diffuse interstitial fibrosis. Which of the following will be seen in this patient's pulmonary function tests?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 48-year-old patient working in the ship repair industry with linear opacities on chest X-ray and diffuse interstitial fibrosis is asbestosis. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern; hence, decreased DLCO will be seen.

Asbestosis results in diffuse interstitial fibrosis leading to restrictive lung disease. Findings of pulmonary function testing:

  • Decreased total lung capacity (TLC), vital capacity (VC), and residual volume (RV) due to diffuse fibrosis
  • In restrictive diseases, both FEV1 (Forced expiratory volume in the first second) and FVC (forced vital capacity) are reduced but FEV1/FVC ratio is normal or even increased as FVC is reduced to a greater degree due to decreased compliance.
  • An FEV1/FVC ratio > 0.7 signifies restrictive lung disorder, whereas <0.7 is seen in obstructive diseases.
  • Damage to the pulmonary capillaries due to fibrosis causes a decrease in diffusing capacity, resulting in reduced DLCO.
  • Flow volume loop in restrictive diseases shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

PFT

Restrictive disease

Decreased

Decreased (<80% predicted)

FEV1

Decreased (<80% predicted)

 Decreased

FEV1% (FEV1/FVC)

Decreased (<0.7)

Normal/ increased (>0.7)

FEF 25-75

<50% predicted

Normal/ decreased

TLC

Normal/ increased

Decreased

RV

Increased

Decreased

DLCO
  • Normal or increased in asthma
  • Decreased in emphysema
  • Decreased in intrinsic restrictive disease

questions.text: A young patient presents with recurrent episodes of excruciating headache on the right side of her head, associated with tearing and redness of the right eye. The headaches last for 1-3 hours and occur once or twice a day at noontime, several weeks at a time. What is the likely diagnosis and best prophylactic treatment?
questions.solution:
The patient with a headache that occurs at the same time everyday with associated autonomic symptoms occuring in clusters is consistent with cluster headaches. Verapamil is the best prophylactic treatment for cluster headaches to reduce the frequency and severity of cluster headaches.

Cluster headache is characterized by severe, one-sided headaches that occur in clusters, often associated with autonomic symptoms, such as tearing, redness of the eye, runny nose and unilateral headache that typically lasts between 15 to 180 minutes. The important feature of this headache is periodicity. At least one of the daily attacks of pain recurs at the same hour each day. It is also associated with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation and rhinorrhea. Occasionally features of Horner's syndrome may be seen. 

The typical cluster headache patient has daily bouts of one to two attacks of relatively short-duration unilateral pain for 8–10 weeks a year; this is usually followed by a pain-free interval that averages a little less than 1 year.

Verapamil, which is a calcium channel block is the drug of choice for the long term prophylaxis of cluster headaches. 

For aborting an acute attack of cluster headache, subcutaneous sumatriptan (6 mg), a selective 5-hydroxytryptamine receptor agonist, is most effective. High-flow oxygen is also effective in the management of an acute attack. 100% oxygen at 10–12 L/min for 15–20 min is required as treatment. If injectable sumatriptan is unavailable, then high-flow oxygen is the next best treatment option (Option B).

Other options:
Options C and D: Migraine presents as an episodic headache associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity, and sensitivity to sound (phonophobia). Common triggers include bright lights, sounds, and hunger. The release of vasoactive peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) by the trigeminal nucleus cells is the theory used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. 

Avoidance of recognized triggers is helpful to avoid symptoms. The various drugs used to treat an acute attack of migraine are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), triptans, CGRP Receptor Antagonists (rimegepant), 5-HT1/F receptor agonists (lasmiditan), and dopamine receptor antagonists (domperidone). 

The drugs used in the prophylaxis include propranolol, valproate, topiramate and flunarizine.
