questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented to the OPD with painless penile lesions and painful lesions on his feet as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image 1 shows circinate balanitis characterized by small, shallow, painless ulcerative lesions on the glans penis. Image 2 shows keratoderma blenorrhagica characterized by skin lesions seen over the palms and soles which begin as vesicles on erythematous bases and progress to pustular keratotic lesions that coalesce to form plaques. Keratoderma blenorrhagica and circinate balanitis are both features of Reiter's syndrome.

The classical triad of Reiter's syndrome consists of:

  1. Urethritis
  2. Acute non-purulent seronegative arthritis
  3. Conjunctivitis

Note: Keratoderma or keratotic sandals is seen in pityriasis rubra pilaris.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes pancreatic necrosectomy. The surgeon decides to place abdominal drains following the procedure. Which of the given suture materials is preferred for securing the drain externally?
questions.solution:
Silk sutures are commonly used to secure external drains.

Silk is a blue/black-colored, multifilament, natural, braided, and non-absorbable suture material derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva. Fibrous encapsulation of the suture occurs in 2 to 3 weeks, and it is absorbed slowly over 1 to 2 years.

It can be used for ligation and suturing when long-term tissue support is necessary. It can also be used for skin closure; however, there is an increased risk of infection and tissue reaction. It can be used for securing drains externally. Silk is not suitable for use with a vascular prosthesis or in tissues requiring prolonged approximation under stress. 


Other options:

Option A: Polydioxanone is a delayed absorbable suture material with a longer wound support period.

Option B: Monocryl (Polygylcaprone) is an absorbable suture material and is used in the subcuticular suturing in the skin. 

Option D: Polypropylene is a monofilament, non-absorbable suture material. It is one of the best sutures for vascular anastomosis.  It is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair, ophthalmic surgery, and general surgical subcuticular skin closure. Polypropylene mesh is used for hernia repair.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman who presented with vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and several episodes of vomiting was diagnosed with complete molar pregnancy. On transvaginal ultrasonography, the following finding is seen in her left ovary. How would you proceed with the management of this patient?

choices.text: U/L oophorectomy with dilation and curettage

questions.solution:
This patient with a diagnosis of complete molar pregnancy and transvaginal ultrasonography showing the presence of multiple theca lutein cysts in the left ovary can be managed with just suction and curettage. Theca lutein cysts, usually regress spontaneously in a period of 2 to 4 months following evacuation of a molar pregnancy, hence can be managed expectantly. Sometimes,  it can undergo torsion and cause marked pelvic pain. In such instances, laparoscopic untwisting of such cysts has to be done.  

Irrespective of the size of the uterus, suction curettage is typically the preferred method for molar evacuation. If the cervix is minimally dilated, it is advisable to perform preoperative cervical dilation using an osmotic dilator. The amount of bleeding during surgery can be higher in cases of molar pregnancy compared to a uterus of similar size that contains nonmolar products. Having large moles necessitates the use of appropriate anesthetic, sufficient intravenous access, and availability of blood-banking services. To perform a molar evacuation, the cervix is mechanically dilated to facilitate the insertion of a large Karman suction cannula. A normal diameter of 10 to 14 mm is common, depending on the size of the uterus. Oxytocin is used during the evacuation process to minimize hemorrhage. Intraoperative sonography is frequently advised to guarantee thorough evacuation of the uterine cavity and reduce the risk of perforation. When the myometrium has contracted, a meticulous yet delicate curettage can be performed with a sharp large-loop Sims curette. The bleeding persists despite the removal of the uterus and the administration of oxytocin. In such cases, further uterotonic drugs are administered. In rare cases, pelvic arterial embolization, uterine packing, or hysterectomy may be required. 

Indications for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their family.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN

Note: Anti-D immunoglobulin to be given to Rh-negative women. The dose is 50 micrograms in the first trimester and 300 micrograms when gestational age is more than 12 weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Oophorectomy is not indicated as the patient has no evidence of ovarian torsion on imaging as well as clinical assessment. Theca lutein cysts tend to spontaneously resolve following evacuation.

Option B: Labor-induced evacuation is very rarely performed owing to increased blood loss and the development of persistent trophoblastic disease.

Option D: Hysterectomy with B/L oophorectomy may be performed in patients who have completed their family along with signs of ovarian torsion due to large size cysts.

questions.text: A patient with end-stage renal disease from diabetic nephropathy is a candidate for renal transplant. A live kidney donor has been identified. Identify the correct statement about renal transplant in this scenario.

choices.text: The donor’s right kidney is preferred for transplant
Nephrectomy of recipient's damaged kidneys is indicated here
The renal vein is anastomosed to the internal iliac vein
The iliac fossa is the ideal site for transplantation

questions.solution:
In this scenario, for the renal transplant from a live kidney donor, the iliac fossa is the ideal site for transplantation in the recipient.

Kidney transplantation is indicated in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD). It is associated with better outcomes and better life expectancy when compared to hemodialysis. The leading causes of ESRD necessitating renal transplant include diabetic nephropathy, hypertension, and chronic glomerulonephritis. 

Nephrectomy of damaged kidneys in the recipient for the causes above is not indicated (option B).  However, nephrectomy is indicated in cases of chronic pyelonephritis, large polycystic kidneys, significant vesicoureteral reflux, or uncontrollable renovascular hypertension.

The donor's left kidney is preferred for transplant because of a longer vascular pedicle (option A). The donor kidney is transplanted into one of the recipient's iliac fossae. This is because of the proximity of the iliac fossae to the bladder and iliac vessels. 

The transplant renal vein is anastomosed to the external or common iliac vein (option C). The transplant renal artery is anastomosed preferably to the internal iliac artery for live donors. However, it can also be anastomosed to the external or common iliac artery. After revascularisation of the transplanted kidney, the ureter is then anastomosed to the bladder.

questions.text: A child with IgA nephropathy comes for a follow-up. Among the given clinical findings, which of the following would indicate a poor prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In patients with IgA nephropathy, persistent hypertension at follow-up is indicative of poor prognosis. 

IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease) is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Clinically, children and young adults present with gross or microscopic hematuria within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory (synpharyngitic presentation) or gastrointestinal infection.

The progression of the disease is slow and variable. There may be heavy proteinuria, hypertension, and chronic renal failure in severe cases. IgA nephropathy in children is associated with an increased risk of progressive disease developing later in adulthood, prompting the need for careful long-term follow-up.

Indicators of poor prognosis at presentation or follow-up include persistent hypertension, decreased renal function, and significant, increasing, or prolonged proteinuria. Histologic evidence of diffuse mesangial proliferation, extensive glomerular crescents, glomerulosclerosis, and diffuse tubulointerstitial changes (such as inflammation and fibrosis) are correlated with a more severe prognosis.

The below image is an immunofluorescence study of IgA nephropathy showing the characteristic IgA deposition in the mesangial regions.

The disease is treated with ACE inhibitors and ARBs to control high blood pressure and proteinuria. If ineffective, corticosteroids and immunosuppressants may be added.

Other options : 

Option B: Serum IgA levels have no diagnostic or prognostic value in IgA nephropathy because they are elevated in only 15% of pediatric patients.

Option C: Serum C3 levels in IgA nephropathy are characteristically normal, and rarely low C3 levels are seen in severe cases.

Option D: A history of recurrent hematuria is common in IgA nephropathy and is not related to prognostication.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Cervical pregnancy can be diagnosed using Rubin's criteria.

Cervical pregnancy is a type of ectopic pregnancy where the implantation occurs in the cervical canal at the level of or below the internal os.

Rubin's criteria for pathological diagnosis of cervical pregnancies:

  • Soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus.
  • Uterine bleeding following amenorrhea, without cramping pain.
  • Products of conception are entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix.
  • A closed internal cervical os and a partially opened external os.

Transvaginal sonographic findings of cervical pregnancy include:

  • An hourglass uterine shape and ballooned cervical canal
  • Gestational tissue at the level of the cervix 
  • Absent intrauterine gestational tissue
  • A portion of the endocervical canal is interposed between the gestation and the endometrial canal.

Treatment: Medical management with methotrexate if vitals are stable and it is diagnosed in the first trimester. Surgical management with suction curettage or hysterectomy is done if vitals are unstable, bleeding uncontrolled, or if the gestation is advanced.

Prior to any procedure, uterine artery embolization, local methotrexate injection into the amnionic sac, ligation of the uterine arteries, or cerclage at the internal os to compress feeding vessels may be done to control bleeding.

The image below shows an ultrasonogram of cervical pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A: Spiegelberg’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy.

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestational sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • Gestational sac connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall

Option B: Godin's sonographic criteria is for the diagnosis of a cesarean scar pregnancy

  • Empty uterine cavity
  • Empty cervical canal
  • A gestational sac in the anterior part of the uterine isthmus
  • Absence of healthy myometrium between the bladder and gestational sac

Option D: Studdiford criteria is used in the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy. It includes:

  • Presence of normal tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past injury/pregnancy.
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula.
  • Presence of a pregnancy-related exclusively to the peritoneal surface and early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation after primary tubal nidation.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is an not a contra-indication for induction of labour?
questions.solution:
Pre-eclampsia is not a contraindication for the induction of labor. 

Contracted pelvis, acute fetal distress and Ca Cervix are all absolute contraindications for the induction of labor.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • IUGR(intra-uterine growth restriction)
  • IUD(Intra-uterine death)
  • Oligohydramnios

Contraindication:

  • Contracted pelvis & CPD
  • Cord prolapse
  • Abnormally implanted placentae
  • Previous classical cesarean/ hysterotomy
  • Active genital herpes
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Malpresentation
  • Pelvic tumor & Ca cervix
  • Overdistention or complete transection of the uterus
  • Two or more previous low transverse caesarean sections

questions.text: Which of the following contrast agent can cause nephrogenic systemic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Gadolinium can cause nephrogenic systemic fibrosis.

Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is a systemic condition that primarily affects the skin of patients with renal impairment. Increased numbers of fibrocytes result in skin thickening and plaque formation which evolves to cause flexion contractures, paraesthesia, and pruritus. As a result, gadolinium-containing contrast is contraindicated in patients with GFR under 30 ml/min

Recent research has also demonstrated radiologically and pathologically detected gadolinium deposition in brain tissue including the dentate nuclei, pons, globus pallidus, and thalamus in patients who have undergone multiple MRI scans using gadolinium-based contrast agents (GBCAs). The clinical significance of this deposition is as yet unknown. Gadolinium is the contrast agent used for MRI. It acts by reducing both the T1/T2 relaxation time of the tissue. The predominant effect is on T1, so post-contrast is a T1-weighted image. Since gadolinium ion is toxic Gd-DTPA is used.

Other options

Ditrazoate, Ioxaglate, and Iohexol are iodinated contrast agents. Ditrazoate is a high-osmolality contrast agent, Ioxaglate is an iso-osmolality contrast agent and Iohexol is a low-osmolality contrast agent.

They increase the risk of Contrast-induced nephropathy(CIN). Acute Kidney Injury Network (AKIN) criteria for AKI be applied for the diagnosis of CIN. AKI is diagnosed if any one of the following criteria is met:

  • Absolute serum creatinine increase >0.3 mg/dL in 48 hours
  • >50% increase in serum creatinine in 7 days
  • Urine output decreased to <0.5 mL/kg/h for at least 6 hours.

Hence alternative imaging methods, without iodinated contrast media, should be chosen in patients with considerably impaired renal function (CKD 4 or 5). In patients with moderate renal impairment (CKD 3) volume expansion with 0.9% saline at 100 mL/h beginning 6 to 2 hours before CT and continuing for 4 to 12 hours after should be done.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with features of diabetic ketoacidosis. After initial management, you ask the nurse to give insulin infusion, who mistakenly administers the insulin as a bolus dose. Following this, you notice a few ECG changes on the monitor. What is the most likely ECG finding in this event?
questions.solution:
Administering insulin bolus will result in hypokalemia, leading to the appearance of U waves on ECG.

A bolus dose of intravenous insulin causes hypokalemia by activating sodium-potassium ATPase in the cell membranes, thereby driving the serum potassium into the cells. The resulting hypokalemia is responsible for certain ECG findings like U waves, flat T waves, ST segment depression, and QT prolongation.

Hypokalemia is defined as a plasma concentration of K+ <3.5 meq/L. Common causes include: 

  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Insulin infusions
  • Diarrhea
  • Use of diuretics
  • Starvation
  • β2-agonists
  • Magnesium deficiency
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism

Option B - ST depression, and not elevation, is seen in hypokalemia. ST elevation is seen in several other conditions like acute myocardial infarction, acute pericarditis, pulmonary embolism, myocarditis, Brugada syndrome and some cases of hyperkalemia.

Option C - Prolonged QT interval is a finding in hypokalemia. Shortened QT interval is seen in hypercalcemia.

Option D - Tall T waves are a finding in hyperkalemia and not hypokalemia.

questions.text: The contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen of a 75-year-old woman shows the following findings. Which Bosniak class does the cyst belong to?
questions.solution:
The presence of a simple renal cyst without any septations, calcifications, or enhancing soft tissue components is classified as Bosniak class I. They do not require treatment or follow-up imaging.

Bosniak classification:

Depending on the CT characteristics the renal cysts are classified mainly into four classes:

Class I: It is a simple benign cyst, without any septations.

Class II: The cyst consists of one or more thin (<1 mm) septa running through them. Class II lesions are benign.

The subcategory class IIF includes lesions with multiple class II features, large hyperdense cysts (>3cm), or hyperdense cysts that are totally intrarenal. These cysts are more complex and do not fit into categories II or III. They require follow-up for up to 5 years to exclude malignancy.

Class III: These are complicated cysts having thickened septa with nodular areas of calcification. The walls of the cyst or septae show enhancement. The class III lesions should be surgically explored or biopsied. <50% will turn out to be malignant.

Class IV: These are malignant lesions with solid enhancing nodules. Surgical removal to be considered.

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate with bilateral conjunctivitis is found to have pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray. Which of the following is likely to be observed in the patient?
questions.solution:
Bilateral conjunctivitis followed by pneumonia in a neonate is suggestive of infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. Infantile pneumonia due to C. trachomatis is typically associated with a staccato cough, which refers to paroxysmal cough associated with an inspiratory breath between each cough.

Chlamydia trachomatis inclusion conjunctivitis usually manifests 1 week after birth. It is usually a venereal infection derived from the cervix or urethra of the mother during delivery. If left untreated, associated systemic diseases such as chlamydial otitis and pneumonia may develop later.

Other options:

Option B: Whooping cough is seen in pertussis, caused by Bordetella pertussis. It is characterized by a continuous bout of coughing at the end of which the child takes a deep breath which makes a 'whooping' sound.

Option C: Bovine cough refers to a hoarse weak cough that is classically described in patients with a left recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, causing vocal cord palsy resulting in an incomplete closure of the glottis. 

Option D: Barking cough, likened to the sound of a seal's bark is typically associated with croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) and epiglotittis.

questions.text: A female presented with loss of pain and temperature, but her touch sensation was intact. Imaging showed cavitation around the central canal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the image showing cavitation around the central canal is syringomyelia. 

Syringomyelia is a progressive disease of the spinal cord in which there is an enlarging cavity in the cord. Syrinx cavities are acquired cavities of the cord in necrosed areas secondary to trauma, myelitis, and spinal cord tumors. It usually presents in adolescence or early adulthood with central cord symptoms. 

Most patients present with regional dissociated sensory loss of pain and temperature of the upper limbs. Touch and vibration senses are intact. The loss of sensation has a 'cape distribution' affecting the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms. Eventually, expansion of the cavity may lead to compression of the long tracts. This results in spasticity and weakness of the legs, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and Horner's syndrome. 

MRI is used for the diagnosis. There is no satisfactory treatment for this condition. Symptomatic syrinx cavities secondary to trauma or infection, are treated with a decompression and drainage procedure.

Other options: 

Option A: Brown-Sequard syndrome occurs due to the transection of the spinal cord only on one side. This results in ipsilateral weakness and loss of joint position and vibration sensation with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

Option B: Tabes dorsalis is a manifestation of neurosyphilis, which occur within a year or up to 10-35 years after primary infection. It causes demyelination of the dorsal column of the spinal cord and presents with bladder disturbances, foot drop, impotence, and ataxia. Loss of position and vibration sense result in a positive Romberg test.

Option C: Syringobulbia occurs when the syrinx of syringomyelia extends into the medulla. It is characterized by palatal or vocal cord paralysis, episodic vertigo, tongue weakness with atrophy, and horizontal nystagmus.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male, who is a known case of PVD, comes with complaints of rest pain. Which of the following values of ankle and brachial pressure correspond to the values that can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
An ABPI of <0.5 is associated with rest pain. The ABPI of 0.4, seen in case of option D, Ankle - 48/36mm Hg, Brachial - 120/80mm Hg, will be corresponding to that of rest pain.

ABPI = Systolic Pressure at Ankle/ Systolic Pressure in the arm(Brachial)

=48/120 = 0.4

 

Other options:

A - ABPI =1.25

B - ABPI = 1

C - ABPI = 0.75

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

3 Histoplasma capsulatum D CD4+ T cell count <150/μL and endemic area
4 Mycobacterium avium complex B CD4+ T cell count <50/μL

 

Following are the NIH/CDC/IDSA 2013 Guidelines for the Prevention of Opportunistic Infections in Persons Infected with HIV

Organism Indication
Pneumocystis jirovecii
  • CD4+ T cell count <200/μL(or)
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis(or)
  • Prior bout of PCP
Toxoplasma gondii
  • TOXO IgG antibody positive and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL(or)
  • Prior toxoplasmic encephalitis and CD4+ T cell count <200/μL
Histoplasma capsulatum Prior documented disease or   CD4+ T cell count <150μL and high risk (endemic area or occupational exposure)
Mycobacterium avium complex(MAC)
  •  CD4+ T cell count <50/μL(or)
  • Prior documented disseminated disease

 

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: A young man presented to the emergency department one hour after the spillage of hot oil on his hands while cooking. On examination, multiple burn injuries are present on his right hand as shown in the image. The injuries are extremely painful when touched with gloves and the capillary refilling is normal.  You would classify this as a
questions.solution:
The degree of burns is second-degree superficial burn. The points that favor the diagnosis are the presence of multiple blisters, tenderness over the injured skin, and the normal capillary refilling time.

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (Partial-thickness burns): In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided as superficial or deep.
    • Superficial partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched.
    • Deep partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and some sensation is preserved. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure.
  • Third-degree burns:  In this degree, there is damage to epidermis, dermis and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the underlying soft tissues.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Burns

  First-degree Second-degree superficial (partial-thickness) Second-degree deep (partial-thickness)

Third-degree (full thickness)

 Fourth-degree (full thickness)
Depth Epidermis Epidermis + superficial dermis Epidermis + most of the dermis (most skin appendages destroyed) Entire dermis + subcutaneous tissue Involves connective tissue, muscle, possibly bone
Colour/texture Red Red, edematous, and blistered Pale, mottled Hard, leathery Pale, dry, charred
Blanchable (capillary refill)  Yes Yes No No No
Pain Painful Painful Painful (only on pinprick) No No
Healing 5-10 days; no scar 10-14 days; no or minimal scar  4-8 weeks, often with scarring and contractures Prolonged, with scarring and contractures, requires skin grafting Requires skin grafting or even amputation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of alcohol abuse causes reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor?
questions.solution:
Naltrexone causes reduced reward response to drinking and reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor.

Before prescribing: Evaluate for possible current opioid use; consider a urine toxicology screen for opioids, including synthetic opioids. Obtain liver function tests and follow up periodically.

Acamprosate, naltrexone, and disulfiram are used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

Other options:

Option A: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine used in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal.

Option B: Acamprosate affects glutamate and GABA neurotransmitter systems, but its alcohol-related action is unclear.

Option D: Disulfiram inhibits the intermediate metabolism of alcohol which causes a build-up of acetaldehyde and a reaction of flushing, sweating, nausea, and tachycardia if a patient drinks alcohol.
